   CT [**Last Name (un) **]/pelvis (FINAL):
   1. Vascular findings unchanged from [**2172-8-25**]. Narrowing of SVC and left

   approximately 5 mm over a region extending 3 cm in craniocaudal
   dimension.
   Indirect evidence of right brachiocephalic vein occlusion, likely
   complete.
   Unchanged narrowing of right pulmonary artery. Splayed but patent

   anterior

   3. No interval change in large infiltrative hypoattenuating right
   hilar/mediastinal mass.
   4. No evidence of metastases in the abdomen or pelvis. Slightly bulky
   left

   5. Anasarca and small amount of peritoneal fluid collecting in the
   pelvis,
   likely related to edema.
   6. Interval tracheal stenting with improved caliber of airway.
   .

   some areas  the tumor cell size approaching that of a small cell
   carcinoma, but much of the tumor has larger nuclei.  Overall, the tumor
   probably fits into the spectrum of a small cell carcinoma of lung.

   .
   58F with concern for small cell carcinoma complicated by SVC syndrome,
   airway compromise requiring Y-stent, pleural effusion, pericardial
   effusion, Pneumothorax, hyponatremia admitted to [**Hospital Unit Name 10**] for radiation
   decompression therapy.
   .
   #. Hypoxemia respiratory failure:  Several reasons for this, including
   right upper and lower lobe collapse, right pleural effusion, right
   pneumothorax. s/p bronchoscopy [**2172-8-26**]; no significant secretions or
   mucus plugs seen on bronchoscopy. Most likely with VQ mismatch because
   of compression of pulmonary vasculature. RLL collapse has improved with
   chest tube but with persistent RUL collapse and small apical
   Pneumothroax. Most recent ABG (10PM) with metabolic acidosis, pO2 99.
   - Pressure support, 14/5 FiO2 50%
   - Sedation with propofol
   - Chest tube, pigtail catheter to allow for parenchymal reexpansion
   tube with low output. Will discuss with IP about whether to remove or
   keep in place given if this is malignant pleural effusion, if effusion
   will recur vs tube as nidus of infection.
   - Tumor decompression therapy to allow for improved ventilation (airway
   compression) and perfusion (vasculature compression)
   .
   #. Suspected small cell lung carcinoma:  Per report. Biopsy results not
   available in OMR. Given associated SVC syndrome, prognosis is likely
   poor. CT [**Last Name (un) **]/pelvis negative for metastases.
   - Radiation therapy, as above
   - Appreciate Heme/onc recs
   -CT Head to evaluate for mets
   .
   #. SVC syndrome:  Incomplete occlusion of SVC; near complete occlusion
   of brachiocephalic veins. Clinically identified by upper extremity and
   facial swelling/plethora and mottled skin. Also with scleral edema.
   Unable to assess jugular venous distension given considerable swelling.
   Seen in appoximately 10% cases of SSLC.
   - Radiation therapy for decompression now that we have a diagnosis, as
   above
   - Appreciate vascular surgery recs
 currently: no stent, discuss code
   status
   .
   #. Pleural effusion:  s/p right pigtail catheter placement [**2172-8-25**]. LDH
   effusion/serum 0.68 (exudate by Light
s criteria). Slightly elevated
   effusion protein. Normal glucose. Consistent with exudative effusion.
   Greatest concern for malignant effusion. Bacterial infection unlikely
   given lymphocyte predominance. Given lymphocyte predominance, may also
   consider TB as we do not know pt
s social or travel history.
   - Pigtail catheter
 d/w IP re continued need, as above
   - Await fluid cytology and cultures
   -Possible PPD placement
   .
   #. Pneumothorax:  s/p chest tube placement. Unclear if this
   precipitated respiratory distress or rather was secondary to
   overinflation during resuscitation period. Risk factor with significant
   smoking history would be blebs.
   - Right chest tube in place
   - Thoracic surgery recs
   .
   #. Pericardial effusion:  Suspected by cardiology to be malignant
   effusion. Felt not to be large enough for percutaneous drainage.
   - Monitor pulsus paradoxus
   - Cardiology recs
   - Check EKG this AM
   .
   #. Hyponatremia:  Differential includes SIADH given lung cancer,
   adrenal insufficiency given recent hyperkalemia and hypotension,
   decreased renal perfusion. Patient reportedly improved with fluid
   restriction, consistent with SIADH, although UNa <10 not consistent
   with this diagnosis. Suspect mixed picture where patient also has
   decreased perfusion of kidneys secondary to SVC obstruction.
   - f/u urine lytes and osms
   - Continue exogenous steroid therapy
   - Continue fluid restriction
   .
   #. Hypotension:  Approximately 24 hours prior to transfer to [**Hospital Unit Name 10**].
   Suspected initially to be secondary to adrenal insufficiency given
   hyperkalemia, acidosis. No evidence of adrenal hemorrhage, mass on CT
   abd/pelvis, although L adrenal slightly bulky. Differential also
   includes tension pneumothorax with improvement secondary to chest tube
   placement. Cardiac tamponade unlikely given absence of tamponade
   physiology on TTE. Septic shock possible given episode of hypothermia.
   - Continue hydrocortisone 100mg IV Q8 hours
   - Management of pericardial and pleural effusions, as above
   - Endocrine recs
   - F/u AM Cortisol
   - Monitor blood, urine cultures. Will reculture for hypothermia, fever.
   .
   #. Metabolic acidosis:  Nongap. No reported GI losses. Suspect
   dilutional secondary to fluid overload. Type IV RTA also possible
   despite normal creatinine; additionally, normal creatinine may be false
   reassurance for normal renal function given muscle wasting. Incomplete
   respiratory compensation on ventilator. [**Month (only) 11**] also be post-hypocapneic
   (Increased respiratory alkalosis, perhaps when tachypneic, with renal
   wasting of HCO3; Pt
s alkalosis may have been quickly corrected when
   put on vent with delayed correction of HCO3)
 however, pt
s HCO3 was
   nl at admission making this unlikely.
   - Urine lytes (Na, K, Cl)
   - Monitor ABG
   .
   #. Leukocytosis:  No clear infection. Likely inflammatory response
   given malignancy, SVC syndrome. Of note, reportedly was hypothermic
   yesterday. If concern ofr infection, will panculture.
   - Monitor blood, thoracentesis cultures
   .
   #. Anemia:  Normocytic. Most acute concern would be DIC; LDH elevated
   although bilirubin normal. ACD possible given malignancy.
   - Haptoglobin
   - Trend hematocrit
   .
   #. s/p cerebral aneurysm repair:  Unclear why patient is disposed to
   having cerebral aneurysm.
   - Continue antiepileptics
   .
   #. Hypertension:
   - Holding metoprolol in context of recent hypotension
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: NPO; Nutrition consult for tube feeds
   Glycemic Control:  ISS (humalog) given high dose steroids

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 58-year-old female with a history of concern for small cell carcinoma of the lung, complicated by superior vena cava (SVC) syndrome, airway compromise requiring Y-stent, pleural effusion, pneumothorax, and hyponatremia. She was admitted to the ICU for radiation decompression therapy.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxemia respiratory failure: The patient has several factors contributing to hypoxemia, including right upper and lower lobe collapse, right pleural effusion, and right pneumothorax. Pressure support, low tidal volume ventilation, and FiO2 adjustments are being made to optimize oxygenation.
2. SVC syndrome: The patient has incomplete occlusion of the SVC, leading to upper extremity and facial swelling. Radiation therapy for decompression is planned.
3. Pleural effusion: The patient has a malignant-appearing pleural effusion, which may require continued pigtail catheter placement and monitoring. Fluid cytology and cultures are pending.
4. Pneumothorax: The patient has a small apical pneumothorax. The right chest tube is in place, and the patient will be monitored for improvement in lung reexpansion.
5. Pericardial effusion: The patient has a suspected malignant pericardial effusion. Cardiology recommendations are being followed, and the patient's condition will be monitored.
6. Hyponatremia

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 58-year-old female with a history of small cell carcinoma (presumptive) and symptoms of superior vena cava (SVC) syndrome. She was admitted to the ICU for radiation decompression therapy and airway compromise requiring Y-stent placement. The patient has multiple medical complications including hypoxemia respiratory failure, hypotension, hyponatremia, metabolic acidosis, leukocytosis, anemia, and hypertension.

Potential Medical Complications:

The patient has been experiencing superior vena cava syndrome (SVC syndrome) with partial compression, airway compromise requiring a Y-stent, pleural effusion likely malignant, and respiratory failure requiring intubation twice.

The patient has been admitted to the hospital for decompression radiation therapy and is scheduled to start chemotherapy today. The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 37.4°C (99.3°F), heart rate of 107 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 135/72 mmHg to 94/59 mmHg, respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100% on CPAP/PSV ventilation.

The patient's physical examination reveals upper body edema, including the face, and difficulty with accommodation. The lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally, and there are chest tubes in place. The abdomen is benign, and the extremities are warm. Neurological assessment is difficult due to the level of sedation.

Laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, hemoglobin, platelet count, lactate dehydrogenase, and blood urea nitrogen. The patient also has hyponatremia and hyperkalemia. Imaging studies reveal a right upper lobe collapse with a consistent appearance of the mass,

   .
   58F with concern for small cell carcinoma complicated by SVC syndrome,
   airway compromise requiring Y-stent, pleural effusion, pericardial
   effusion, Pneumothorax, hyponatremia admitted to [**Hospital Unit Name 10**] for radiation
   decompression therapy.
   .
   #. Hypoxemia respiratory failure:  Several reasons for this, including
   right upper lobe collpase due to tumor, right pleural effusion. Right
   pneumothorax appears to have resolved. S/p bronchoscopy [**2172-8-26**]; no
   significant secretions or mucus plugs seen on bronchoscopy. Most likely
   with VQ mismatch because of compression of pulmonary vasculature. With
   persistent RUL collapse. Most recent ABG with continued metabolic
   acidosis.
   - Pt on AC due to increasing acidosis overnight. Change to PS as
   tolerated
   - Sedation with propofol
   - Chest tube, pigtail catheter to allow for parenchymal reexpansion
   still draining >250cc fluid
   - Tumor decompression with radiation and chemotherapy to allow for
   improved ventilation (airway compression) and perfusion (vasculature
   compression)
   - sputum cx to eval for PNA
 pt does not have much sputum. Will send
   if/when sputum obtained.
   .
   #. Hypotension: Now with elevated BP although ranges from SBP 90-140s.
   Suspected initially to be secondary to adrenal insufficiency given
   hyperkalemia, acidosis. No evidence of adrenal hemorrhage, mass on CT
   abd/pelvis, although L adrenal slightly bulky. Differential also
   includes tension pneumothorax with improvement secondary to chest tube
   placement. Cardiac tamponade unlikely given absence of tamponade
   physiology on TTE. Septic shock possible given episode of hypothermia.
   - Continue hydrocortisone per endo recs
 decreased to hydrocortisone
   to 40mg q12hrs
   -Hold hydrocortisone on days when pt receives dexa for chemo
   - Management of pericardial and pleural effusions, as above
   -  send sputum cx to look for source of possible infection (not yet
   sent as pt has no/little sputum)
   - Monitor blood, urine cultures.
   .
   #. Probable small cell lung carcinoma: per pathology, the tumor
   probably fits into the spectrum of a small cell carcinoma of lung.
   Given associated SVC syndrome, prognosis is likely poor. CT
   [**Last Name (un) **]/pelvis/head (head: PRELIM) negative for metastases.
   - Radiation therapy
 next session [**8-31**]
   - started on chemotherapy - etoposide, carboplatin
 Hem/Onc may
   increase etoposide
   - given allopurinol 300 mg once
   - given 2 L NS @ 150 cc/hr for chemo
 only during chemo
   - follow up tumor lysis markers qday per Hem/Onc
   - Appreciate Heme/onc recs
   .
   #. SVC syndrome:  Incomplete occlusion of SVC; near complete occlusion
   of brachiocephalic veins. Clinically identified by upper extremity and
   facial swelling/plethora and mottled skin. Also with scleral edema.
   Unable to assess jugular venous distension given considerable swelling.
   Seen in appoximately 10% cases of SSLC. Improved edema on exam today
   compared to admission.
   - Radiation therapy and chemotherapy for decompression
   - Vascular surgery signed off- no stent; discuss code status
   .
   #. Pleural effusion:  s/p right pigtail catheter placement [**2172-8-25**]. LDH
   effusion/serum 0.68 (exudate by Light
s criteria). Slightly elevated
   effusion protein. Normal glucose. Greatest concern for malignant
   effusion. Bacterial infection unlikely given lymphocyte predominance.
   Given lymphocyte predominance, may also consider TB as we do not know
   pt
s social or travel history although AFB screen of fluid negative.
   - Pigtail catheter
 once output <250cc, will d/w IP re: removal
   - f/u fluid cytology and cultures
   .
   #. Pneumothorax:  appears resolved on CXR. s/p chest tube placement.
   Unclear if this precipitated respiratory distress or rather was
   secondary to overinflation during resuscitation period. Risk factor
   with significant smoking history would be blebs.
   - Right chest tube in place
 will f/u with IP re: removal
   .
   #. Pericardial effusion:  Suspected by cardiology to be malignant
   effusion. Felt not to be large enough for percutaneous drainage. EKG
   without signs of electrical alternans but does have low voltages.
   - Monitor pulsus paradoxus
   - f/u Cardiology recs
   - ECHO if exam changes
   .
   #. Hyponatremia:  Improving with Na 132 today. Differential includes
   SIADH given lung cancer, adrenal insufficiency given recent
   hyperkalemia and hypotension, decreased renal perfusion. Patient
   reportedly improved with fluid restriction, consistent with SIADH,
   although UNa <10 not consistent with this diagnosis. Also, Na did not
   decrease with NS given for chemo suggesting this may not be SIADH.
   Suspect mixed picture where patient also has decreased perfusion of
   kidneys secondary to SVC obstruction. [**Month (only) 11**] also be contribution of
   possible RTA type IV with hypoaldo and decreased sodium absorption,
   although UNa low.
   - Continue exogenous steroid therapy
   - Fluid restriction except when receiving fluids for chemotherapy
   (received NS 2L for chemo)
   -F/u endo recs
   -[**Month (only) 11**] get renal consult depending on endo recs
   .
   #. Metabolic acidosis:  Complicated by new repiratory acidosis
   overnight, but this resolved with change in vent settings in HPI.
   Nongap metabolic acidosis. No reported GI losses. Suspect dilutional
   secondary to fluid overload. Type IV RTA also possible despite normal
   creatinine; additionally, normal creatinine may be false reassurance
   for normal renal function given muscle wasting. [**Month (only) 11**] also be
   post-hypocapneic (Increased respiratory alkalosis, perhaps when
   tachypneic, with renal wasting of HCO3; Pt
s alkalosis may have been
   quickly corrected when put on vent with delayed correction of HCO3)
   however, pt
s HCO3 was nl at admission making this unlikely.
   - may be type IV RTA
   - Monitor ABG
   - will f/u endo recs for renal insufficiency, possible renal consult
   .
   #. Leukocytosis:  Improving WBC. No clear infection. Likely
   inflammatory response given malignancy, SVC syndrome. If concern for
   infection, will panculture.
   - Monitor blood, thoracentesis cultures

   58F with concern for small cell carcinoma complicated by SVC syndrome,
   airway compromise requiring Y-stent, pleural effusion, pericardial
   effusion, Pneumothorax, hyponatremia admitted to [**Hospital Unit Name 10**] for radiation
   decompression therapy.
   .
   #. Hypoxemia respiratory failure:  Several reasons for this, including
   right upper and lower lobe collapse, right pleural effusion, right
   pneumothorax. s/p bronchoscopy [**2172-8-26**]; no significant secretions or
   mucus plugs seen on bronchoscopy. Most likely with VQ mismatch because
   of compression of pulmonary vasculature. RLL collapse has improved with
   chest tube but with persistent RUL collapse and small apical
   Pneumothroax. Most recent ABG with continued metabolic acidosis.
   - Pt on AC due to increasing acidosis overnight.
   - Sedation with propofol
   - Chest tube, pigtail catheter to allow for parenchymal reexpansion
   - Tumor decompression therapy to allow for improved ventilation (airway
   compression) and perfusion (vasculature compression)
   - sputum cx to eval for PNA
   .
   #. Hypotension: Now with elevated BP although ranges from SBP 90-140s.
   Suspected initially to be secondary to adrenal insufficiency given
   hyperkalemia, acidosis. No evidence of adrenal hemorrhage, mass on CT
   abd/pelvis, although L adrenal slightly bulky. Differential also
   includes tension pneumothorax with improvement secondary to chest tube
   placement. Cardiac tamponade unlikely given absence of tamponade
   physiology on TTE. Septic shock possible given episode of hypothermia.
   - Continue hydrocortisone per endo recs
 decreased to hydrocortisone
   to 40mg q12hrs
   -Hold hydrocortisone on days when pt receives dexa for chemo
   - Management of pericardial and pleural effusions, as above
   -  send sputum cx to look for source of possible infection (not yet
   sent)
   - Monitor blood, urine cultures.
   .
   #. Probable small cell lung carcinoma:  Per report. Biopsy results not
   available in OMR. Given associated SVC syndrome, prognosis is likely
   poor. CT [**Last Name (un) **]/pelvis/head, head negative for metastases.
   - Radiation therapy
 next session [**8-31**]
   - started on chemotherapy - etoposide, carboplatin
   - given allopurinol 300 mg once
   - given 2 L NS @ 150 cc/hr for chemo
   - follow up tumor lysis markers
   - Appreciate Heme/onc recs
   .
   #. SVC syndrome:  Incomplete occlusion of SVC; near complete occlusion
   of brachiocephalic veins. Clinically identified by upper extremity and
   facial swelling/plethora and mottled skin. Also with scleral edema.
   Unable to assess jugular venous distension given considerable swelling.
   Seen in appoximately 10% cases of SSLC.
   - Radiation therapy and chemotherapy for decompression now that we have
   a diagnosis, as above
   - Appreciate vascular surgery recs
 currently: no stent, discuss code
   status
   .
   #. Pleural effusion:  s/p right pigtail catheter placement [**2172-8-25**]. LDH
   effusion/serum 0.68 (exudate by Light
s criteria). Slightly elevated
   effusion protein. Normal glucose. Consistent with exudative effusion.
   Greatest concern for malignant effusion. Bacterial infection unlikely
   given lymphocyte predominance. Given lymphocyte predominance, may also
   consider TB as we do not know pt
s social or travel history although
   AFB screen of fluid negative.
   - Pigtail catheter
 d/w IP re continued need, as above
   - f/u fluid cytology and cultures
   .
   #. Pneumothorax:  s/p chest tube placement. Unclear if this
   precipitated respiratory distress or rather was secondary to
   overinflation during resuscitation period. Risk factor with significant
   smoking history would be blebs.
   - Right chest tube in place
   - Thoracic surgery recs
   .
   #. Pericardial effusion:  Suspected by cardiology to be malignant
   effusion. Felt not to be large enough for percutaneous drainage. EKG
   without signs of electrical alternans but does have low voltages.
   - Monitor pulsus paradoxus
   - f/u Cardiology recs
   .
   #. Hyponatremia:  Improving with Na 132 today. Differential includes
   SIADH given lung cancer, adrenal insufficiency given recent
   hyperkalemia and hypotension, decreased renal perfusion. Patient
   reportedly improved with fluid restriction, consistent with SIADH,
   although UNa <10 not consistent with this diagnosis. Suspect mixed
   picture where patient also has decreased perfusion of kidneys secondary
   to SVC obstruction.
   - Continue exogenous steroid therapy
   - ?? Fluid restriction vs fluids for chemotherapy (received NS 2L for
   chemo)
   .
   #. Metabolic acidosis:  Nongap. No reported GI losses. Suspect
   dilutional secondary to fluid overload. Type IV RTA also possible
   despite normal creatinine; additionally, normal creatinine may be false
   reassurance for normal renal function given muscle wasting. Incomplete
   respiratory compensation on ventilator. [**Month (only) 11**] also be post-hypocapneic
   (Increased respiratory alkalosis, perhaps when tachypneic, with renal
   wasting of HCO3; Pt
s alkalosis may have been quickly corrected when
   put on vent with delayed correction of HCO3)
 however, pt
s HCO3 was
   nl at admission making this unlikely.
   - may be type IV RTA given + urine anion gap and TTKG 3.88
   - Monitor ABG
   .
   #. Leukocytosis:  Improving WBC with no clear infection. Likely
   inflammatory response given malignancy, SVC syndrome. If concern for
   infection, will panculture.
   - Monitor blood, thoracentesis cultures
   - sent sputum cx
   .
   #. Anemia:  Normocytic. Hct stable. Most acute concern would be DIC;
   LDH elevated although bilirubin normal. ACD possible given malignancy.
   - Haptoglobin normal

Summary:
Based on the information provided in the progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old female with a history of small cell lung carcinoma (SCLC) who has been admitted to the ICU for radiation decompression therapy. The patient is currently experiencing multiple medical complications, including respiratory failure, adrenal insufficiency, airway obstruction, electrolyte and fluid disorder, SVC syndrome, pleural effusion, pneumothorax, pericardial effusion, hyponatremia, metabolic acidosis, leukocytosis, anemia, and hypertension.

The patient's respiratory failure is due to hypoxemia with a right upper and lower lobe collapse, right pleural effusion, and right pneumothorax. The SVC syndrome is causing facial swelling, mottled skin, and scleral edema. The patient has an exudative pleural effusion with lymphocyte predominance, which may indicate a malignant effusion. The pneumothorax is likely secondary to the patient's significant smoking history and overinflation during resuscitation. The pericardial effusion is suspected to be malignant but not large enough for percutaneous drainage. The patient also has hyponatremia, which could be due to SIADH, adrenal insufficiency, or decreased renal perfusion. There is also evidence of metabolic acidosis, possibly dilutional secondary to fluid overload or type IV RTA.

The patient is on mechanical ventilation with increased PSV to 14/5 and decreased propofol. She is also receiving heparin sodium (prophylaxis), pantoprazole (protonix), and other medications. The patient's lab results show elevated WBC, Hct, and LDH, as well as abnormalities in electrolytes and kidney function.

Overall, the patient is critically ill with multiple organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS) due to her underlying malignancy and its complications. The patient's code status is full code.

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 37.6°C, heart rate of 106 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 105-158 mmHg, respiratory rate of 17 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%. Her rhythm is sinus tachycardia.

The patient is intubated and sedated, with upper body edema including the face, and difficulty with accommodation. There are no abnormal lung sounds, and chest tubes are in place. The abdomen is benign, and extremities are warm. Neuro assessment is limited due to sedation.

Summary:
The patient is a critically ill individual with small cell lung cancer, experiencing hypoxic respiratory failure and superior vena cava (SVC) syndrome. They have been admitted to the ICU and are currently receiving chemotherapy. The patient's vital signs indicate a sinus tachycardia with a heart rate of 106 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 158/78 mmHg to 105/60 mmHg, respiratory rate of 17 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%. The patient's weight has increased from 53 kg to 55.7 kg since admission. 

The patient's fluid balance shows an input of 3,216 mL and output of 1,331 mL, with a total balance of 1,885 mL. They are receiving multiple medications, including propofol, pantoprazole, heparin sodium, dexamethasone, etoposide, carboplatinum, nicotine patch, and others. The patient's laboratory results reveal a white blood cell count of 12.9 K/uL, hemoglobin of 9.7 g/dL, platelet count of 286 K/uL, blood glucose levels ranging from 117 mg/dL to 143 mg/dL, and other lab values within normal limits.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is experiencing hypoxic respiratory failure, which can lead to further deterioration in oxygenation and ventilation. Close

   58F with concern for small cell carcinoma complicated by SVC syndrome,
   airway compromise requiring Y-stent, pleural effusion, pericardial
   effusion, Pneumothorax, hyponatremia admitted to [**Hospital Unit Name 10**] for radiation
   decompression therapy.
   .
   #. Hypoxemia respiratory failure:  No vent changes made overnight. Pt
   did not tolerate PS very well overnight. Several reasons for worsening
   respiratory failure, including right upper lobe collpase due to tumor,
   right pleural effusion. Right pneumothorax appears to have resolved. No
   significant secretions or mucus plugs seen on bronchoscopy [**8-26**]. Most
   likely with VQ mismatch because of compression of pulmonary
   vasculature. Pt spiked temperature, concern for VAP. Most recent ABG
   with continued metabolic acidosis.
   - Change to PS as tolerated
   - Sedation with propofol
   - Chest tube, pigtail catheter to allow for parenchymal reexpansion
   still draining >250cc fluid; per IP, continue with tubes at this time.
   - Tumor decompression with radiation and chemotherapy to allow for
   improved ventilation (airway compression) and perfusion (vasculature
   compression)
   - f/u sputum cx.
   .
   # Pause on telemetry: Pt had episodes of pauses overnight on tele.
   Cards called
 reassuring that resumed beat is narrow complex
 lack of
   P wave suggests it may be junctional. This may have been positional,
   given that it occurred as pt was turned. [**Month (only) 11**] be related to worsening
   pericardial effusion although no electrical alternans on EKG during
   episodes. K slightly elevated but not at level to demonstrate EKG
   changes. Beta blocker was restarted yesterday, so concern for toxicity,
   although restarted at dose lower than home dose and glucagon had no
   effect. Pauses decreased in frequency and duration on their own without
   intervention.
   -Appreciate cards recs
   -Monitor tele
   -?repeat ECHO
   .
   #. Hypotension: Now with elevated BP although ranges from SBP 90-140s.
   Suspected initially to be secondary to adrenal insufficiency given
   hyperkalemia, acidosis. No evidence of adrenal hemorrhage, mass on CT
   abd/pelvis, although L adrenal slightly bulky. Differential also
   includes tension pneumothorax with improvement secondary to chest tube
   placement. Cardiac tamponade unlikely given absence of tamponade
   physiology on TTE. Septic shock possible given episode of hypothermia.
   - Continue hydrocortisone per endo recs
decrease Hydrocortisone to 20
   mg IV Q12H. Then 15mg AM, 10mg PM (?tmrw?).
   - Hold hydrocortisone on days when pt receives dexa for chemo
   - Management of pericardial and pleural effusions, as above
   - f/u cultures
   .
   #. Probable small cell lung carcinoma: per pathology, the tumor
   probably fits into the spectrum of a small cell carcinoma of lung.
   Given associated SVC syndrome, prognosis is likely poor. CT
   [**Last Name (un) **]/pelvis/head (head: PRELIM) negative for metastases. -Hem/Onc:
   increased etoposide to 80mg/m2;
   - Fluids only with chemo
   - Tumor lysis labs qday
   - Radiation therapy
 next session [**8-31**]
   - started on chemotherapy - etoposide, carboplatin
   - given 1 L NS @ 150 cc/hr for chemo
 only during chemo
   - Appreciate Heme/onc recs
   - ? Team meeting with Hem/Onc and ICU team to discuss prognosis and
   goals of care prior to family meeting.
   .
   #. SVC syndrome:  Incomplete occlusion of SVC; near complete occlusion
   of brachiocephalic veins. Clinically identified by upper extremity and
   facial swelling/plethora and mottled skin. Also with scleral edema.
   Unable to assess jugular venous distension given considerable swelling.
   Seen in appoximately 10% cases of SSLC. Improved edema on exam today
   compared to admission.
   - Radiation therapy and chemotherapy for decompression
   - Vascular surgery signed off- no stent; discuss code status
   .
   #. Pleural effusion:  s/p right pigtail catheter placement [**2172-8-25**]. LDH
   effusion/serum 0.68 (exudate by Light
s criteria). Slightly elevated
   effusion protein. Normal glucose. Greatest concern for malignant
   effusion. Bacterial infection unlikely given lymphocyte predominance.
   Given lymphocyte predominance, may also consider TB as we do not know
   pt
s social or travel history although AFB screen of fluid negative.
   Keep tube in place per IP for now.
   - Pigtail catheter
 once output <250cc, will d/w IP re: removal
   - f/u fluid cytology and cultures
   .
   #. Pneumothorax:  appears resolved on CXR. s/p chest tube placement.
   Unclear if this precipitated respiratory distress or rather was
   secondary to overinflation during resuscitation period. Risk factor
   with significant smoking history would be blebs. Keep tube in place for
   now per IP.
   - Right chest tube in place
 will f/u with IP re: removal
   .
   #. Pericardial effusion:  Suspected by cardiology to be malignant
   effusion. Felt not to be large enough for percutaneous drainage. EKG
   without signs of electrical alternans but does have low voltages.
   - Monitor pulsus paradoxus
   - ECHO if exam changes
   .
   #. Hyponatremia:  Improving with Na 139 today. Differential includes
   SIADH given lung cancer, adrenal insufficiency given recent
   hyperkalemia and hypotension, decreased renal perfusion. Patient
   reportedly improved with fluid restriction, consistent with SIADH,
   although UNa <10 not consistent with this diagnosis. Also, Na did not
   decrease with NS given for chemo suggesting this may not be SIADH.
   Suspect mixed picture where patient also has decreased perfusion of
   kidneys secondary to SVC obstruction. [**Month (only) 11**] also be contribution of
   possible RTA type IV with hypoaldo and decreased sodium absorption,
   although UNa low.
   - Continue exogenous steroid therapy
 decrease per Endo recs
   - Fluid restriction except when receiving fluids for chemotherapy
   (received NS 1L for chemo)
   - F/u endo recs
   -?Renal consult
 endo not very helpful re: why she
s hyponatremic w/
   inconsistent UNa.
   .
   #. Metabolic acidosis:  Complicated by new repiratory acidosis
   overnight, but this resolved with change in vent settings in HPI.
   Nongap metabolic acidosis. No reported GI losses. Suspect dilutional
   secondary to fluid overload. Type IV RTA also possible despite normal
   creatinine; additionally, normal creatinine may be false reassurance
   for normal renal function given muscle wasting. [**Month (only) 11**] also be
   post-hypocapneic (Increased respiratory alkalosis, perhaps when
   tachypneic, with renal wasting of HCO3; Pt
s alkalosis may have been
   quickly corrected when put on vent with delayed correction of HCO3)
   however, pt
s HCO3 was nl at admission making this unlikely.
   - may be type IV RTA
   - Monitor ABG
   - will f/u endo recs for renal insufficiency, possible renal consult
   .
   #. Leukocytosis:  WBC trending downwards possibly due to 2 cycles
   chemotherapy. No clear infection although pt did have temp yesterday.
   Likely inflammatory response given malignancy, SVC syndrome.
   - Monitor blood, urine, sputum, thoracentesis cultures
   .
   #. Anemia:  Normocytic. Hct stable. Most acute concern would be DIC;
   LDH elevated although bilirubin normal. Haptoglobin normal. ACD
   possible given malignancy.
   - Trend hematocrit
   .

   .
   58F with likely small cell carcinoma complicated by SVC syndrome,
   airway compromise requiring Y-stent, pericardial effusion, resolved
   pleural effusion and pneumothorax, and electrolytes disturbances
   admitted to [**Hospital Unit Name 10**] for radiation decompression therapy and chemotherapy.
   .
   #. Hypoxic respiratory failure:  No vent changes made overnight as pt
   did not tolerate PS very well yesterday. Pt spiked temperature with new
   infiltrate on CXR concerning for VAP given ventilator course.  Other
   causes of prolonged respiratory failure include right upper lobe
   collpase due to tumor. Right pleural effusion and right pneumothorax
   appear to have resolved.  No significant secretions or mucus plugs seen
   on bronchoscopy [**8-26**]. Most likely with VQ mismatch because of
   compression of pulmonary vasculature. Most recent ABG with continued
   metabolic acidosis.
   -Start vancomycin/cefepime to cover MRSA and pseudomonas for VAP
   - Change to PS as tolerated
 pt may require prolonged weaning course
   - Sedation with propofol
   - Chest tube will  most likely stay in place until extubation to
   prevent new pneumothorax
   - Tumor decompression with radiation and chemotherapy to allow for
   improved ventilation (airway compression) and perfusion (vasculature
   compression)
   - resend sputum culture
   .
   # Sinus Pause on telemetry: Pt had episodes of sinus pauses overnight
   on tele. Cards was called
 reassuring that resumed beat is narrow
   complex
 lack of P wave suggests it may be junctional. This may have
   been positional, given that it occurred as pt was turned although it
   has continued today, less frequently. [**Month (only) 11**] be related to worsening
   pericardial effusion although no electrical alternans on EKG during
   episodes. K+ slightly elevated but not at level to demonstrate EKG
   changes. Beta blocker was restarted yesterday, so concern for toxicity,
   although restarted at dose lower than home dose and glucagon had no
   effect. Pauses decreased in frequency and duration on their own without
   intervention.
   -Continue to hold metoprolol
   -pacer pads in place and atropine at bedside
   -Things to watch for: HR<40, hemodynamic instability, if resumed beat
   is wide complex; dopamine will be pressor of choice
   -Appreciate cards recs
   -Monitor tele
   -?repeat ECHO
   -Kayexalate 15mg PO x1 given hyperkalemia and electrical changes
   .
   #. Small cell lung carcinoma: per pathology, the tumor probably fits
   into the spectrum of a small cell carcinoma of lung. Given associated
   SVC syndrome, prognosis is likely poor. CT [**Last Name (un) **]/pelvis/head negative
   for metastases.  Currently on chemotherapy and s/p XRT x2.
   - Stop checking tumor lysis labs
   - Radiation therapy
 no session today as pt getting chemo; t/b with
   rad onc re: next session
   - given 1 L NS @ 150 cc/hr for chemo
 fluids only needed during chemo
   - Appreciate Heme/onc recs
   - Team meeting with Hem/Onc and ICU team to discuss prognosis
   .
   #. Hyponatremia: Improving with Na 139 today. Appears to be mixed
   picture of SIADH plus hypoaldosteronism leading to Type IV RTA. Pt was
   not really fluid restricted given she received fluids for chemo with
   improvement of Na, and UNa low making SIADH less likely. Would also
   expect high UNa with hypoaldosteronism.  There may be some contribution
   of SVC obstruction leading to decreased kidney perfusion. Pt may have
   hypoaldosteronism without adrenal insufficiency, as endo thinks this is
   less likely now to be adrenal insufficiency.
   - Will d/w endocrinology re: clarification of hyponatremia and f/u recs
   - Continue fluids for chemotherapy
   - Hydrocortisone 15mg IV qAM and 10mg qPM per Endo
 will d/w endo need
   for hydrocortisone given pt receiving high dose dexa with chemotherapy,
   although dexamethasone has low mineralocorticoid action.
   .
   # Hyperkalemia: K increased to 5.3 today with sinus pauses on EKG.
   Unclear if they are related but concerning as this is new. [**Month (only) 11**] be due
   to chemotherapy and tumor lysis although remaining TL labs are normal.
   [**Month (only) 11**] also be due to hypoaldosteronism.
   -kayexalate 15mg PO x1
   -F/u Cardiology recs
   -F/u endocrinology recs
   .
   #. Metabolic acidosis:  Most likely due to hypoaldosteronism leading to
   Type IV RTA, although pt with normal creatinine.  Normal creatinine may
   be false reassurance for normal renal function given muscle wasting.
   - Monitor ABG
   - will f/u endo recs for hypoaldosteronism
   .
   #. SVC syndrome:  Incomplete occlusion of SVC; near complete occlusion
   of brachiocephalic veins. Clinically identified by upper extremity and
   facial swelling/plethora and mottled skin. Also with scleral edema.
   Unable to assess jugular venous distension given considerable swelling.
   Seen in appoximately 10% cases of SSLC. Improved edema on exam today
   compared to admission.
   - Radiation therapy and chemotherapy for decompression
   .
   #. Pleural effusion:  s/p right pigtail catheter placement [**2172-8-25**],
   removed [**2172-8-31**]. LDH effusion/serum 0.68 (exudate by Light
s criteria).
   Greatest concern for malignant effusion.
   - f/u fluid cytology and cultures
   .
   #. Pneumothorax:  appears resolved on CXR.
   - Will keep tube in place most likely until pt extubated to prevent
   recurrence of pneumothorax with removal
   .
   #. Pericardial effusion:  Suspected by cardiology to be malignant
   effusion. Felt not to be large enough for percutaneous drainage. EKG
   without signs of electrical alternans but does have low voltages. [**Month (only) 11**]
   have contributed to sinus pauses overnight.
   - F/u cardiology recs
   - ECHO if exam changes
   .
   #. Leukocytosis:  WBC trending downwards possibly due to 2 cycles
   chemotherapy. Pt most likely with VAP but leukopenia in setting of
   infection is also concerning.  [**Month (only) 11**] have also been due to inflammatory
   response given malignancy and SVC syndrome and is decreasing as they
   are treated.
   - Monitor blood, urine, sputum, thoracentesis cultures
   -Trend WBC
   .
   #. Anemia:  Normocytic. Hct stable. Most acute concern would be DIC;
   LDH elevated although bilirubin normal. Haptoglobin normal. ACD
   possible given malignancy.
   - Trend hematocrit
   .
   #. s/p cerebral aneurysm repair:  Unclear why patient is disposed to
   having cerebral aneurysm. Pt mental status difficult to assess. She has
   a number of chronic changes on head CT.
   -continue antiepileptics.
   -If MS not improved in 2 days, will do repeat Head CT
   .
   #. Hypertension: Metoprolol d/c
d held in setting of pauses given
   concern for beta blocker toxicity. Pt remains hypertensive.
   -Continue holding metoprolol
   -Hydralazine to keep SBP 140s-160s.
   -Monitor propofol and BP carefully when giving hydralazine to avoid
   hypotensive episodes

Summary:
The patient is a 58-year-old male with a new diagnosis of small cell carcinoma and Superior Vena Cava (SVC) syndrome. He is currently intubated and mechanically ventilated due to respiratory failure caused by extrinsic and intrinsic narrowing of the distal trachea and bronchi on the right side, on the background of Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD). There are also new right lower lobe (RLL) and left lower lobe (LLL) infiltrates, which are concerning for pneumonia, specifically ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).

The patient's SVC syndrome has significantly improved over the past 48 hours. He continues to receive radiation therapy (XRT) and chemotherapy. His right pleural effusion has resolved after chest tube drainage, which was determined to be malignant. The chest tube has been removed, and there is no evidence of air leak.

The patient's small cell carcinoma is demonstrating a clinical response to XRT and chemotherapy. Radiation Oncology and Oncology services have been involved, providing recommendations and guidance. Monitoring for tumor lysis syndrome is essential.

There is no evidence of pericardial effusion tamponade on examination, so continued monitoring is recommended. The patient's hyponatremia has improved and is attributed to adrenal insufficiency, hypodole, and syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (SIADH) secretion. Steroids are being continued.

   Assessment and Plan
 TACHYCARDIA, OTHER
 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name 2**])

   58F with likely small cell carcinoma complicated by SVC syndrome,
   airway compromise requiring Y-stent, pericardial effusion, resolved
   pleural effusion and pneumothorax, and electrolytes disturbances
   admitted to [**Hospital Unit Name 10**] for radiation decompression therapy and chemotherapy.
   .
   #. Hypoxic respiratory failure:  No vent changes made overnight as pt
   did not tolerate PS very well yesterday. Pt spiked temperature with new
   infiltrate on CXR concerning for VAP given ventilator course.  Other
   causes of prolonged respiratory failure include right upper lobe
   collpase due to tumor. Right pleural effusion and right pneumothorax
   appear to have resolved.  No significant secretions or mucus plugs seen
   on bronchoscopy [**8-26**]. Most likely with VQ mismatch because of
   compression of pulmonary vasculature. Most recent ABG with continued
   metabolic acidosis.
   -Start vancomycin/cefepime to cover MRSA and pseudomonas for VAP
   - Change to PS as tolerated
 pt may require prolonged weaning course
   - Sedation with propofol
   - Chest tube will  most likely stay in place until extubation to
   prevent new pneumothorax
   - Tumor decompression with radiation and chemotherapy to allow for
   improved ventilation (airway compression) and perfusion (vasculature
   compression)
   - resend sputum culture
   .
   # Sinus Pause on telemetry: Pt had episodes of sinus pauses overnight
   on tele. Cards was called
 reassuring that resumed beat is narrow
   complex
 lack of P wave suggests it may be junctional. This may have
   been positional, given that it occurred as pt was turned although it
   has continued today, less frequently. [**Month (only) 11**] be related to worsening
   pericardial effusion although no electrical alternans on EKG during
   episodes. K+ slightly elevated but not at level to demonstrate EKG
   changes. Beta blocker was restarted yesterday, so concern for toxicity,
   although restarted at dose lower than home dose and glucagon had no
   effect. Pauses decreased in frequency and duration on their own without
   intervention.
   -Continue to hold metoprolol
   -pacer pads in place and atropine at bedside
   -Things to watch for: HR<40, hemodynamic instability, if resumed beat
   is wide complex; dopamine will be pressor of choice
   -Appreciate cards recs
   -Monitor tele
   -?repeat ECHO
   -Kayexalate 15mg PO x1 given hyperkalemia and electrical changes
   .
   #. Small cell lung carcinoma: per pathology, the tumor probably fits
   into the spectrum of a small cell carcinoma of lung. Given associated
   SVC syndrome, prognosis is likely poor. CT [**Last Name (un) **]/pelvis/head negative
   for metastases.  Currently on chemotherapy and s/p XRT x2.
   - Stop checking tumor lysis labs
   - Radiation therapy
 no session today as pt getting chemo; t/b with
   rad onc re: next session
   - given 1 L NS @ 150 cc/hr for chemo
 fluids only needed during chemo
   - Appreciate Heme/onc recs
   - Team meeting with Hem/Onc and ICU team to discuss prognosis
   .
   #. Hyponatremia: Improving with Na 139 today. Appears to be mixed
   picture of SIADH plus hypoaldosteronism leading to Type IV RTA. Pt was
   not really fluid restricted given she received fluids for chemo with
   improvement of Na, and UNa low making SIADH less likely. Would also
   expect high UNa with hypoaldosteronism.  There may be some contribution
   of SVC obstruction leading to decreased kidney perfusion. Pt may have
   hypoaldosteronism without adrenal insufficiency, as endo thinks this is
   less likely now to be adrenal insufficiency.
   - Will d/w endocrinology re: clarification of hyponatremia and f/u recs
   - Continue fluids for chemotherapy
   - Hydrocortisone 15mg IV qAM and 10mg qPM per Endo
 will d/w endo need
   for hydrocortisone given pt receiving high dose dexa with chemotherapy,
   although dexamethasone has low mineralocorticoid action.
   .
   # Hyperkalemia: K increased to 5.3 today with sinus pauses on EKG.
   Unclear if they are related but concerning as this is new. [**Month (only) 11**] be due
   to chemotherapy and tumor lysis although remaining TL labs are normal.
   [**Month (only) 11**] also be due to hypoaldosteronism.
   -kayexalate 15mg PO x1
   -F/u Cardiology recs
   -F/u endocrinology recs
   .
   #. Metabolic acidosis:  Most likely due to hypoaldosteronism leading to
   Type IV RTA, although pt with normal creatinine.  Normal creatinine may
   be false reassurance for normal renal function given muscle wasting.
   - Monitor ABG
   - will f/u endo recs for hypoaldosteronism
   .
   #. SVC syndrome:  Incomplete occlusion of SVC; near complete occlusion
   of brachiocephalic veins. Clinically identified by upper extremity and
   facial swelling/plethora and mottled skin. Also with scleral edema.
   Unable to assess jugular venous distension given considerable swelling.
   Seen in appoximately 10% cases of SSLC. Improved edema on exam today
   compared to admission.
   - Radiation therapy and chemotherapy for decompression
   .
   #. Pleural effusion:  s/p right pigtail catheter placement [**2172-8-25**],
   removed [**2172-8-31**]. LDH effusion/serum 0.68 (exudate by Light
s criteria).
   Greatest concern for malignant effusion.
   - f/u fluid cytology and cultures
   .
   #. Pneumothorax:  appears resolved on CXR.
   - Will keep tube in place most likely until pt extubated to prevent
   recurrence of pneumothorax with removal
   .
   #. Pericardial effusion:  Suspected by cardiology to be malignant
   effusion. Felt not to be large enough for percutaneous drainage. EKG
   without signs of electrical alternans but does have low voltages. [**Month (only) 11**]
   have contributed to sinus pauses overnight.
   - F/u cardiology recs

   58F with likely small cell carcinoma complicated by SVC syndrome,
   airway compromise requiring Y-stent, pericardial effusion, resolved
   pleural effusion and pneumothorax, and electrolytes disturbances
   admitted to [**Hospital Unit Name 10**] for radiation decompression therapy and chemotherapy.
   .
   #. Hypoxic respiratory failure:  Increased RR from 14 to 20 for
   respiratory acidosis.  Pt spiked temperature with new infiltrate on CXR
   concerning for VAP given ventilator course.  Other causes of prolonged
   respiratory failure include right upper lobe collapse due to tumor.
   Right pleural effusion appears slightly worse today.  Right
   pneumothorax appear to have resolved.  No significant secretions or
   mucus plugs seen on bronchoscopy [**8-26**].  Most likely with VQ mismatch
   because of compression of pulmonary vasculature. Most recent ABG with
   continued metabolic acidosis.
   - decrease vancomycin to q24hrs for elevated creatinine today to cover
   MRSA VAP
   - continue cefepime to cover MRSA and pseudomonas VAP
   - wean ventilator as tolerated, likely to stay on AC today
   - plan to titrate down propofol and trial of fentanyl for pain
   management
   - chest tube to stay in place as per IP recs until patient is off vent
   - s/p 3 days of chemotherapy.  Possible radiation treatment today to
   allow for improved ventilation (airway compression) and perfusion
   (vasculature compression)
   - resend sputum culture
   .
   # Sinus Pause on telemetry: Pt had episodes of sinus pauses on tele 2
   nights ago.  It is reassuring that resumed beat is narrow complex
   lack of P wave suggests it may be junctional. This may have been
   positional, given that it occurred as pt was turned although it has
   continued today, less frequently. [**Month (only) 11**] be related to worsening
   pericardial effusion although no electrical alternans on EKG during
   episodes. K+ slightly elevated but not at level to demonstrate EKG
   changes. Cardiology consult thinks it
s vagally mediated.  Pauses
   decreased in frequency and duration on their own without intervention.
   - continue to hold metoprolol
   - as per cardiology, no need for transcutaneous pacing
   - monitor vitals, HR, hemodynamic instability, if resumed beat is wide
   complex; dopamine will be pressor of choice
   - no urgent need for echo, but get one before pt is discharged from
   hospital
   - Kayexalate 15mg PO x1 given hyperkalemia and electrical changes
   .
   #. Small cell lung carcinoma: per pathology, the tumor probably fits
   into the spectrum of a small cell carcinoma of lung. Given associated
   SVC syndrome, prognosis is likely poor. CT [**Last Name (un) **]/pelvis/head negative
   for metastases.  s/p 3 days of chemo and 2 sessions of XRT.
   - stop checking tumor lysis labs
   - radiation therapy, 3^rd session likely today
   - f/u heme/onc recs
   .
   #. Hyponatremia: Improving with Na 140 today. Appears to be mixed
   picture of SIADH plus hypoaldosteronism leading to Type IV RTA. Pt was
   not really fluid restricted given she received fluids for chemo with
   improvement of Na, and UNa low making SIADH less likely. Would also
   expect high UNa with hypoaldosteronism.  There may be some contribution
   of SVC obstruction leading to decreased kidney perfusion. Pt may have
   hypoaldosteronism without adrenal insufficiency, as endo thinks this is
   less likely now to be adrenal insufficiency.
   - f/u any endocrine recs
   - patient appears prerenal on labs, increase free water flushes to 250
   cc q4hrs
   - Hydrocortisone 15mg IV qAM and 10mg qPM per Endo
   - UA, eosinophils, and urine lytes
   .

   .
   #. Metabolic acidosis:  Most likely due to hypoaldosteronism leading to

   - will f/u endo recs for hypoaldosteronism
   - renal consult
   .

   of brachiocephalic veins. Clinically identified by upper extremity and
   facial swelling/plethora and mottled skin. Also with scleral edema.

s criteria).

   .

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 58-year-old male with a new diagnosis of small cell carcinoma and Superior Vena Cava (SVC) syndrome. He is currently in respiratory failure due to extrinsic and intrinsic narrowing of the distal trachea and bronchi on the right, on a background of Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD). The patient also has evidence of new right lower lobe (RLL) and left lower lobe (LLL) infiltrates, concerning for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). He is being treated with empirical antimicrobials and mechanical ventilation. The patient's SVC syndrome has improved over the past 48 hours, and he has resolved right pleural effusion and pneumothorax. His small cell cancer is responding to radiation therapy and chemotherapy. The patient has hypotension, hypertension, fluid overload, renal failure, metabolic acidosis, sinus dysrhythmia, anemia, and is receiving nutritional support.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is multifactorial, primarily due to extrinsic and intrinsic narrowing of the distal trachea and bronchi on the right, on a background of COPD. The presence of new RLL and LLL infiltrates also raises concern for VAP.
2. Pneumonia: The new infiltrates in the RLL and LLL suggest the possibility of pneumonia. VAP is a common complication in mechanically ventilated

 The progressive interstitial pulmonary abnormality and right
   pleural effusion probably due to pulmonary edema. More severe
   consolidative abnormalities at both lung bases are also concerning for
   pneumonia. Right apical pleural tube in place. No pneumothorax. ET tube
   and nasogastric tube in standard placements. Heart size normal,
   unchanged. The bulk of the large right upper lobe mass has decreased
   over the past several days.
   Assessment and Plan
   58F with likely small cell carcinoma complicated by SVC syndrome,
   airway compromise requiring Y-stent, pericardial effusion, resolved
   pleural effusion and pneumothorax, and electrolytes disturbances
   admitted to [**Hospital Unit Name 10**] for radiation decompression therapy and chemotherapy.
   .
   #. Hypoxic respiratory failure:  Increased RR from 14 to 20 for
   respiratory acidosis.  Pt spiked temperature with new infiltrate on CXR
   concerning for VAP given ventilator course.  Other causes of prolonged
   respiratory failure include right upper lobe collapse due to tumor.
   Right pleural effusion appears slightly worse today.  Right
   pneumothorax appear to have resolved.  No significant secretions or
   mucus plugs seen on bronchoscopy [**8-26**].  Most likely with VQ mismatch
   because of compression of pulmonary vasculature. Most recent ABG with
   continued metabolic acidosis.
   - decrease vancomycin to q24hrs for elevated creatinine today to cover
   MRSA VAP
   - continue cefepime to cover MRSA and pseudomonas VAP
   - wean ventilator as tolerated, likely to stay on AC today
   - plan to titrate down propofol and trial of fentanyl for pain
   management
   - chest tube to stay in place as per IP recs until patient is off vent
   - s/p 3 days of chemotherapy.  Possible radiation treatment today to
   allow for improved ventilation (airway compression) and perfusion
   (vasculature compression)
   - resend sputum culture
   .
   # Sinus Pause on telemetry: Pt had episodes of sinus pauses on tele 2
   nights ago.  It is reassuring that resumed beat is narrow complex
   lack of P wave suggests it may be junctional. This may have been
   positional, given that it occurred as pt was turned although it has
   continued today, less frequently. [**Month (only) 11**] be related to worsening
   pericardial effusion although no electrical alternans on EKG during
   episodes. K+ slightly elevated but not at level to demonstrate EKG
   changes. Cardiology consult thinks it
s vagally mediated.  Pauses
   decreased in frequency and duration on their own without intervention.
   - continue to hold metoprolol
   - as per cardiology, no need for transcutaneous pacing
   - monitor vitals, HR, hemodynamic instability, if resumed beat is wide
   complex; dopamine will be pressor of choice
   - no urgent need for echo, but get one before pt is discharged from
   hospital
   - Kayexalate 15mg PO x1 given hyperkalemia and electrical changes
   .
   #. Small cell lung carcinoma: per pathology, the tumor probably fits
   into the spectrum of a small cell carcinoma of lung. Given associated
   SVC syndrome, prognosis is likely poor. CT [**Last Name (un) **]/pelvis/head negative
   for metastases.  s/p 3 days of chemo and 2 sessions of XRT.
   - stop checking tumor lysis labs
   - radiation therapy, 3^rd session likely today
   - f/u heme/onc recs
   .
   #. Hyponatremia: Improving with Na 140 today. Appears to be mixed
   picture of SIADH plus hypoaldosteronism leading to Type IV RTA. Pt was
   not really fluid restricted given she received fluids for chemo with
   improvement of Na, and UNa low making SIADH less likely. Would also
   expect high UNa with hypoaldosteronism.  There may be some contribution
   of SVC obstruction leading to decreased kidney perfusion. Pt may have
   hypoaldosteronism without adrenal insufficiency, as endo thinks this is
   less likely now to be adrenal insufficiency.
   - f/u any endocrine recs
   - patient appears prerenal on labs, increase free water flushes to 250
   cc q4hrs
   - Hydrocortisone 15mg IV qAM and 10mg qPM per Endo
   - UA, eosinophils, and urine lytes
   .
   # Hyperkalemia: K increased to 5.3 today but no episodes of sinus
   pauses on EKG.  [**Month (only) 11**] also be due to hypoaldosteronism.
   -kayexalate 15mg PO x1
   -F/u Cardiology recs
   -F/u endocrinology recs
   .
   #. Metabolic acidosis:  Most likely due to hypoaldosteronism leading to
   Type IV RTA, although pt with normal creatinine.  Normal creatinine may
   be false reassurance for normal renal function given muscle wasting.
   - will f/u endo recs for hypoaldosteronism
   - renal consult
   .
   #. SVC syndrome:  Incomplete occlusion of SVC; near complete occlusion
   of brachiocephalic veins. Clinically identified by upper extremity and
   facial swelling/plethora and mottled skin. Also with scleral edema.
   Unable to assess jugular venous distension given considerable swelling.
   Seen in appoximately 10% cases of SSLC. Improved edema on exam today
   compared to admission.
   - Radiation therapy and chemotherapy for decompression
   .
   #. Pleural effusion:  s/p right pigtail catheter placement [**2172-8-25**],
   removed [**2172-8-31**]. LDH effusion/serum 0.68 (exudate by Light
s criteria).
   Greatest concern for malignant effusion.
   - f/u fluid cytology and cultures
   .
   #. Pneumothorax:  appears resolved on CXR.
   - Will keep tube in place most likely until pt extubated to prevent
   recurrence of pneumothorax with removal
   .
   #. Pericardial effusion:  Suspected by cardiology to be malignant
   effusion. Felt not to be large enough for percutaneous drainage. EKG
   without signs of electrical alternans but does have low voltages. [**Month (only) 11**]
   have contributed to sinus pauses overnight.
   - F/u cardiology recs
   - ECHO if exam changes
   .
   #. Leukocytosis:  WBC trending downwards possibly due to 2 cycles
   chemotherapy. Pt most likely with VAP but leukopenia in setting of
   infection is also concerning.  [**Month (only) 11**] have also been due to inflammatory
   response given malignancy and SVC syndrome and is decreasing as they
   are treated.
   - Monitor blood, urine, sputum, thoracentesis cultures
   -Trend WBC
   - f/u heme/onc on need for neupogen
   .
   #. Anemia:  Normocytic. Hct stable. Most acute concern would be DIC;
   LDH elevated although bilirubin normal. Haptoglobin normal. ACD
   possible given malignancy.
   - Trend hematocrit
   .
   #. s/p cerebral aneurysm repair:  Unclear why patient is disposed to
   having cerebral aneurysm. Pt mental status difficult to assess. She has
   a number of chronic changes on head CT.
   -continue antiepileptics.
   -If MS not improved in 2 days, will do repeat Head CT
   .
   #. Hypertension: Metoprolol d/c
d held in setting of pauses given
   concern for beta blocker toxicity. Pt remains hypertensive.
   -Continue holding metoprolol
   -Hydralazine to keep SBP 140s-160s.
   -Monitor propofol and BP carefully when giving hydralazine to avoid
   hypotensive episodes

The patient is a 58-year-old female with a history of small cell lung carcinoma (SCLC) and Superior Vena Cava (SVC) syndrome. She has been admitted to the ICU for radiation decompression therapy and chemotherapy. The patient's current condition includes hypoxic respiratory failure, sinus pauses on telemetry, small cell lung carcinoma, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis, SVC syndrome, pleural effusion, pneumothorax, pericardial effusion, leukocytosis, anemia, and hypertension.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxic respiratory failure: The patient's increased respiratory rate and low oxygen saturation indicate respiratory distress. This could be due to her underlying lung disease or complications such as pneumonia or ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
2. Sinus pauses on telemetry: The patient's episodes of sinus pauses may be related to worsening pericardial effusion or vagally mediated. Continuous monitoring of vital signs and heart rate is recommended, and a cardiology consult has been requested.
3. Small cell lung carcinoma: The patient's prognosis is likely poor given the aggressive nature of SCLC. Close monitoring of tumor lysis labs and follow-up with oncology recommendations is essential.
4. Hyponatremia: The patient's sodium levels are low, which may be due to syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH) or hypoaldosteronism. Fluid

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 58-year-old female with a history of small cell lung carcinoma, presenting with symptoms such as hypoxic respiratory failure, sinus pauses, SVC syndrome, pleural effusion, pneumothorax, pericardial effusion, leukocytosis, anemia, and hypertension. The patient has been admitted to the ICU for radiation decompression therapy and chemotherapy.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxic respiratory failure: The patient's increased respiratory rate and metabolic acidosis indicate a worsening respiratory status. This could be due to a ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) or right upper lobe collapse caused by the tumor. The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation, and efforts are being made to wean her off it.

2. SVC syndrome: The patient has incomplete occlusion of the superior vena cava (SVC), leading to upper extremity and facial swelling. Radiation therapy and chemotherapy are planned to decompress the SVC syndrome.

3. Pleural effusion: The patient had a right pleural effusion, which appears slightly worse today. The effusion is most likely malignant. Fluid cytology and cultures should be followed up.

4. Pneumothorax: The patient had a pneumothorax, but it appears resolved on the chest X-ray. The chest tube will most likely stay in place until the patient is extubated to prevent recurrence.

5. Pericardial effusion: Cardiology suspects

 The progressive interstitial pulmonary abnormality and right

   Assessment and Plan
   58F with likely small cell carcinoma complicated by SVC syndrome,
   airway compromise requiring Y-stent, pericardial effusion, resolved
   pleural effusion and pneumothorax, and electrolytes disturbances
   admitted to [**Hospital Unit Name 10**] for radiation decompression therapy and chemotherapy.
   .
   #. Hypoxic respiratory failure:  Continues to have mixed respiratory
   and metabolic acidosis despite increasing RR yesterday.  Peak pressures
   in the high 38-40 and plat pressures of 30 last night so decreased TV
   and increased RR to maintain same MV of 12 but to decrease airway
   pressures. Pressure decreased slightly with these changes with plat of
   25.  Her oxygenation was worse last night with saturation decreased to
   91%.  Her PEEP was increased.  Respiratory status also complicated by
   possible underlying COPD given smoking history with possible air
   stacking/trapping, possible VAP or other pulmonary infection,
   atelectasis/consolidation seen at bilateral bases.  PTX not seen on
   CXR.
   - decrease vancomycin to q24hrs for elevated creatinine to cover MRSA
   VAP
   - continue cefepime and Cipro to cover MRSA and pseudomonas VAP
   - wean ventilator as tolerated, likely to stay on AC today
   - plan to titrate down propofol and trial of fentanyl for pain
   management
   - chest tube to stay in place as per IP recs until patient is off vent
   - s/p 3 days of chemotherapy.  Will need to touch base with heme/onc
   and rad/onc regarding plans for XRT or more chemo.
   - f/u speciation of sputum cx
   - IP checked Y stent placement on xray and looks the same, if continued
   problems with high pressures will consider future bronch
   .
   # Altered Mental Status: Patient has been off propofol for almost 24
   hours and continues to not follow commands.  She does withdraw from
   noxious stimuli but cannot cooperate for neuro exam.  Differential
   includes seizure (given hx), toxic metabolic, Infection, progression of
   cancer.  Will repeat her CT head today to eval for any changes and plan
   for EEG to eval for possible non-convulsive seizure activity.  Also
   plan for LP to eval for possible leptomeningeal spread of her cancer.
   - f/u EEG (with plans to consult neuro if abnormal)
   -f/u head CT read
   - LP with CSF sent for cytology and cx
   .

   into the spectrum of a small cell carcinoma of lung. Given associated

   chemo/radiation

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 58-year-old female with a history of small cell lung carcinoma, admitted to the ICU for radiation decompression therapy and chemotherapy. She has multiple medical complications including hypoxic respiratory failure, altered mental status, acute renal failure, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis, superior vena cava (SVC) syndrome, pleural effusion, pneumothorax, pericardial effusion, sinus pauses, leukocytosis, anemia, and hypertension.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxic respiratory failure: The patient continues to have mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis despite increasing respiratory rate. Peak pressures are high, and oxygenation is worsening. Possible underlying COPD, air stacking/trapping, ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), atelectasis/consolidation at bilateral bases.
2. Altered mental status: The patient is off propofol for almost 24 hours and remains disoriented. Differential includes seizure, toxic metabolic, infection, progression of cancer. Repeating her CT head today to evaluate for any changes, planning for EEG to evaluate for possible non-convulsive seizure activity, and performing a lumbar puncture (LP) to evaluate for possible leptomeningeal spread of cancer.
3. Acute renal failure: In the setting of chemotherapy with carboplatin, suspecting that the chemo is the cause, possibly contributing to renal failure due to decreased kidney perfusion

   MICU Attending Addendum:
   Experienced bradycardia (junctional rhythm), hypotension and skin
   mottling.  Some improvement with suctioning, but significant resistance
   to catheter advancement.  Urgent bronchscopy revealed tip of ETT
   migrated between silcone Y-stent  and tracheal wall.  ETT repositioned
   under fiberoptic bronchoscopy guidance, and copious milky white
   secretions aspirated.  (See complete procedure note).  Tolerated well.
   BP, HR and SaO2 improved dramatically.
   ------ Protected Section Addendum Entered By:[**Name (NI) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **], MD
   on:[**2172-9-2**] 15:38 ------
Summary:
The patient is a 58-year-old male with a new diagnosis of small cell carcinoma and superior vena cava syndrome. He is experiencing respiratory failure, primarily due to extrinsic and intrinsic narrowing of the distal trachea and bronchi on the right, on a background of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). There are also new right lower lobe (RLL) and left lower lobe (LLL) infiltrates, concerning for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). The patient has been started on empirical antimicrobials and will continue mechanical ventilation while monitoring arterial blood gases (ABG). Sputum culture is also being monitored. 

The patient's mental status is very slow to awaken and he is off propofol for over 24 hours. A repeat head CT did not reveal any new pathology. An MRI is not possible due to the presence of intracranial surgical clips. There is a plan for an electroencephalogram (EEG) to assess for non-convulsive status epilepticus. Lumbar puncture for cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis is being performed to evaluate for carcinomatous meningitis. Neurological consultation is being considered, as the patient's mental status may be toxic metabolic.

The patient had SVC syndrome but it has improved over the past 48 hours. He has completed chemotherapy and is continuing radiation therapy. The right pleural effusion has resolved after chest tube drainage, which was malignant

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient's chief complaint is respiratory failure. The patient remains intubated and mechanically ventilated. They are off sedation for over 24 hours with poor mental status. The patient received radiation therapy to the right chest this morning.

The patient's medical history is significant for small cell carcinoma with superior vena cava (SVC) syndrome, airway compromise requiring Y-stent, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). The patient also has pulmonary infiltrates in the right lower lobe (RLL) and left lower lobe (LLL), which are concerning for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). The patient is on empirical antimicrobials for VAP.

The patient's mental status is very slow to awaken and they are off Propofol for over 24 hours. A repeat head CT was unrevealing for new pathology. An MRI is not possible due to the presence of intracranial surgical clips. There is an underlying seizure disorder, and the plan is to perform an EEG (continuous) to assess for non-convulsive status epilepticus. A lumbar puncture (LP) for cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis is also planned to assess for carcinomatous meningitis. A neurological consultation is considered.

The patient has shown improvement in SVC syndrome over the past 48 hours. The patient completed chemotherapy and continues with radiation therapy. The right pleural effusion has resolved after chest

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old male with a new diagnosis of small cell carcinoma and superior vena cava (SVC) syndrome. The patient's respiratory failure is multifactorial, primarily due to extrinsic and intrinsic narrowing of the distal trachea and bronchi on the right, on a background of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). There are also new right lower lobe (RLL) and left lower lobe (LLL) infiltrates, concerning for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).

The patient's mental status is very slow to awaken and off propofol for over 24 hours. A repeat head CT was unrevealing for new pathology. An MRI is not possible due to the presence of intracranial surgical clips. The underlying seizure disorder (on kepra) is being assessed with an EEG to evaluate for non-convulsive status epilepticus. A lumbar puncture for cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis is planned to evaluate for carcinomatous meningitis. Neurological consultation is considered.

The SVC syndrome has improved significantly over the past 48 hours, and chemotherapy has been completed. Radiation therapy (XRT) will continue. The right pleural effusion has resolved after chest tube drainage and was determined to be malignant.    Assessment and Plan
   58F with likely small cell carcinoma complicated by SVC syndrome,
   airway compromise requiring Y-stent, pericardial effusion, resolved
   pleural effusion and pneumothorax, and electrolytes disturbances
   admitted to [**Hospital Unit Name 10**] for radiation decompression therapy and chemotherapy.
   .
   #. Hypoxic respiratory failure:  Pt had transient hypoxia with skin
   mottling yesterday afternoon and bronch revealed ETT lodged between
   tracheal wall and Y stent.  ETT was repositioned and hypoxia improved
   although pt was still autoPEEPing.  This AM her RR was decreased as she
   was breathing over it.  Respiratory status also complicated by possible
   underlying COPD given smoking history with possible air
   stacking/trapping, possible VAP or other pulmonary infection,
   atelectasis/consolidation seen at bilateral bases.  PTX not seen on
   CXR.
   - holding vanc as her level is elevated; will check level in AM and
   readjust dose as needed
   - continue cefepime and Cipro to cover MRSA and pseudomonas VAP
   - wean ventilator as tolerated, likely to stay on AC today
   - plan to titrate down propofol and trial of fentanyl for pain
   management
   - chest tube to stay in place as per IP recs until patient is off vent
   - s/p 3 days of chemotherapy
   - f/u speciation of sputum cx
   .
   # Altered Mental Status: Patient has been off propofol and still not
   moving extremities or grossly following commands.  She does withdraw
   from noxious stimuli but cannot cooperate for neuro exam.  Differential
   includes seizure (given hx), toxic metabolic, Infection, progression of
   cancer.  Repeat CT head unchanged from prior.  EEG today to eval for
   possible non-convulsive seizure activity.  Also plan for LP to eval for
   possible leptomeningeal spread of her cancer.
   - f/u EEG (with plans to consult neuro if abnormal)
   -f/u head CT read
   - LP and will send CSF sent for cytology and cx
   .
   #. Small cell lung carcinoma: per pathology, the tumor probably fits
   into the spectrum of a small cell carcinoma of lung. Given associated
   SVC syndrome, prognosis is likely poor. CT [**Last Name (un) **]/pelvis/head negative
   for metastases.  s/p 3 days of chemo and 2 sessions of XRT.  Initially,
   XRT was clinical emergency - they might've treated lots of nl tissue;
   needs formal tissue planning session to reduce amount they radiate;
   will wait until new scans/doing clinically better.  Rad/onc to do
   formal planning session next Tues or so to let chemo work for a bit
   Per heme/onc, it will be a few weeks before next round of chemo.
   - continue neupogen for 10 day course
   - f/u heme/onc recs
   - start neutropenic precautions
   .
   # Acute Renal failure: In setting of chemo with carboplatin.  Renal
   spun urine yesterday and casts consistent with ATN.  Plan to optimize
   SBP 120s-130s, consider pRBCs to keep increased intravascular delivery
   to kidneys. Ordered renal US  for obstruction.
   - gently hydrate with IVFs
   - will check SvO2 to eval oxygenation and need for possible pRBC
   transfusion
   - trend Cr and renally dose meds
   - continue to hold vanc as level too elevated
   .
   #. Metabolic acidosis:  Realize this is now a gap metabolic acidosis as
   her albumin is low.  Her metabolic acidosis is likely related to
   uremia.  Goal pH is 7.3-7.35.
   - will f/u endo recs
   - f/u renal recs
   - started on Bicitra
   .
   #. Hyponatremia: Resolved.  Unclear etiology on admission- thought to
   be secondary to possible adrenal insufficency (now discarded) or
   possibly SIADH.  Low UNa does not exclude SIADH; renal recommends
   rechecking urine lytes with saline load.  (In SIADH, UNa should
   increase and Uosm should remain high).
   - f/u any endocrine and renal recs
   .
   # Hyperkalemia: Continues to have hyperkalemia without further episodes
   of sinus pauses on EKG.  [**Month (only) 11**] be due to hypoaldosteronism but unlikely
   per endocrine.  Etiology unclear. Not Type IV RTA b/c urine sodium not
   >30. Checking serum renin, aldosterone.  Could be hyperkalemia in the
   setting of cell death from chemo.
   -F/u Cardiology recs
   -F/u endocrinology recs
   - f/u renal recs
   - f/u renin, [**Male First Name (un) **]
   .
   #. SVC syndrome:  Incomplete occlusion of SVC; near complete occlusion
   of brachiocephalic veins. Clinically identified by upper extremity and
   facial swelling/plethora and mottled skin. Also with scleral edema.
   Unable to assess jugular venous distension given considerable swelling.
   Seen in appoximately 10% cases of SSLC. Improved edema on exam compared
   to admission.
   - Radiation therapy and chemotherapy for decompression
   .
   #. Pleural effusion:  s/p right pigtail catheter placement [**2172-8-25**],
   removed [**2172-8-31**]. LDH effusion/serum 0.68 (exudate by Light
s criteria).
   Greatest concern for malignant effusion.  Cytology nonspecific.
   Cultures of fluid all preliminary negative.
   .
   #. Pneumothorax:  appears resolved on CXR.
   - Will keep tube in place most likely until pt extubated to prevent
   recurrence of pneumothorax with removal
   .
   #. Pericardial effusion:  Suspected by cardiology to be malignant
   effusion. Felt not to be large enough for percutaneous drainage. EKG
   without signs of electrical alternans but does have low voltages.
   - F/u cardiology recs
   .
    # Sinus Pause on telemetry: Pt had episodes of sinus pauses on tele
   night of [**8-30**] without any since.  Cardiology consult thinks it
   vagally mediated.  Pauses decreased in frequency and duration on their
   own without intervention.
   - continue to hold metoprolol
   - as per cardiology, no need for transcutaneous pacing
   - monitor vitals, HR, hemodynamic instability, if resumed beat is wide
   complex; dopamine will be pressor of choice
   - no urgent need for echo, but get one before pt is discharged from
   hospital
   .
   #. Leukocytosis:  WBC trending downwards possibly due to 3 days of
   chemotherapy. Pt most likely with VAP but leukopenia in setting of
   infection is also concerning.  [**Month (only) 11**] have also been due to inflammatory
   response given malignancy and SVC syndrome and is decreasing as they
   are treated.
   - Monitor blood, urine, sputum, thoracentesis cultures
   -Trend WBC
   - continue neupogen for 10 day course
   .
   #. Anemia:  Normocytic. Hct stable. Most acute concern would be DIC;
   LDH elevated although bilirubin normal. Haptoglobin normal. ACD
   possible given malignancy.
   - Trend hematocrit
   .
   #. s/p cerebral aneurysm repair:  Unclear why patient is disposed to
   having cerebral aneurysm. Pt mental status difficult to assess. She has
   a number of chronic changes on head CT.
   -continue antiepileptics.
   -f/u repeat head CT read
   .
   #. Hypertension: Metoprolol d/c
d held in setting of pauses given
   concern for beta blocker toxicity. Pt remains hypertensive.
   -Continue holding metoprolol
   -Hydralazine PRN to keep SBP 140s-160s.
   -Monitor propofol and BP carefully when giving hydralazine to avoid
   hypotensive episodes

The patient is a 58-year-old female with a history of small cell lung carcinoma, who is currently admitted to the ICU for radiation decompression therapy and chemotherapy. The patient experienced transient hypoxia with skin mottling yesterday afternoon, and bronchoscopy revealed that the endotracheal tube (ETT) was lodged between the tracheal wall and Y stent. The ETT was repositioned, and hypoxia improved, although the patient was still autoPEEPing. The respiratory status is complicated by possible underlying chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) given the patient's smoking history with possible air stacking/trapping, possible ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) or other pulmonary infection, and atelectasis/consolidation seen at bilateral bases.

The patient's altered mental status is likely due to several factors, including seizure, toxic metabolic, infection, or progression of cancer.
