   - IP checked Y stent placement on xray and looks the same, if continued
   problems with high pressures will consider future bronch
   .
   # Altered Mental Status: Patient has been off propofol for almost 24
   hours and continues to not follow commands.  She does withdraw from
   noxious stimuli but cannot cooperate for neuro exam.  Differential
   includes seizure (given hx), toxic metabolic, Infection, progression of
   cancer.  Will repeat her CT head today to eval for any changes and plan
   for EEG to eval for possible non-convulsive seizure activity.  Also
   plan for LP to eval for possible leptomeningeal spread of her cancer.
   - f/u EEG (with plans to consult neuro if abnormal)
   -f/u head CT read
   - LP with CSF sent for cytology and cx
   .
   #. Small cell lung carcinoma: per pathology, the tumor probably fits
   into the spectrum of a small cell carcinoma of lung. Given associated
   SVC syndrome, prognosis is likely poor. CT [**Last Name (un) **]/pelvis/head negative
   for metastases.  s/p 3 days of chemo and 2 sessions of XRT. -RAD ONC:
   Discussing with Med Onc, Don't know when Med Onc plans to give more
   chemo. Initially, XRT was clinical emergency - they might've treated
   lots of nl tissue; needs formal tissue planning session to reduce
   amount they radiate; will wait until new scans/doing clinically better;
   Will do formal planning session next Tues or so to let chemo work for a
   bit. Small cell is responsive to chemo so hoping this will shrink so
   they can irradiate less and preserve more nl tissue.  -HEM/ONC: Chemo
   completed. Will be a few weeks before next round.
   - started neupogen yesterday with plan for 10 day course
   - will discuss with heme/onc and rad/onc their plans for future
   chemo/radiation
   - f/u heme/onc recs
   .
   # Acute Renal failure: In setting of chemo with carboplatin.  Suspect
   chemo is cause although prerenal as well based on FeNa of 0.3.  RTA may
   also play a role.
   - gently hydrate with IVFs
   - f/u renal recs, plan to spin urine to look for sediment and casts
   - trend Cr and renally dose meds
   - check vanc level
   .
   #. Hyponatremia: Resolved with Na 140 today.  Not Type IV RTA b/c urine
   sodium not >30 (If RTA Type IV, SC Heparin can cause this). Most likely
   ATN [**2-10**] hypoperfusion. Low UNa does not exclude SIADH (REc: recheck
   urine lytes with saline load- in SIADH, UNa should increase and Uosm
   should remain high), optimize BP 120s-130s, consider pRBCs to keep
   increased intravascular delivery to kidneys, check serum renin,
   aldosterone. Check renal US  for obstruction (ordered).
   Unclear etiology on admission as appeared to be mixed picture of SIADH
   plus hypoaldosteronism leading to Type IV RTA.  However now thought by
   endocrine that pt was not adrenally insufficient or hypoaldo.  There
   may be some contribution of SVC obstruction leading to decreased kidney
   perfusion.
   - f/u any endocrine recs
   - patient appears prerenal on labs, increase free water flushes to 150
   cc q4hrs
   .
   # Hyperkalemia: Continues to have hyperkalemia without further episodes
   of sinus pauses on EKG.  [**Month (only) 11**] be due to hypoaldosteronism but unlikely
   per endocrine.  Etiology unclear.
   -F/u Cardiology recs
   -F/u endocrinology recs
   - f/u renal recs
   .
   #. Metabolic acidosis:  -Acid/Base: so, looking at her ABG, she has a
   respiratory acidosis and a gap metabolic acidosis (which is why her pH
   is lower than you'd expect from either process alone). SO, up to this
   point, we've been saying her metabolic acidosis is non-gap and
   attributed to Type IV RTA (she may have been non-gap, or we may not
   have calculated it properly given her albumin). BUT, our differential
   is now MUDPILES. Her metabolic acidosis may be due to her uremia.
   - will f/u endo recs
   - f/u renal recs
   .
   #. SVC syndrome:  Incomplete occlusion of SVC; near complete occlusion
   of brachiocephalic veins. Clinically identified by upper extremity and
   facial swelling/plethora and mottled skin. Also with scleral edema.
   Unable to assess jugular venous distension given considerable swelling.
   Seen in appoximately 10% cases of SSLC. Improved edema on exam today
   compared to admission.
   - Radiation therapy and chemotherapy for decompression
   .
   #. Pleural effusion:  s/p right pigtail catheter placement [**2172-8-25**],
   removed [**2172-8-31**]. LDH effusion/serum 0.68 (exudate by Light
s criteria).
   Greatest concern for malignant effusion.  Cytology nonspecific.
   Cultures of fluid all preliminary negative.
   .
   #. Pneumothorax:  appears resolved on CXR.
   - Will keep tube in place most likely until pt extubated to prevent
   recurrence of pneumothorax with removal
   .
   #. Pericardial effusion:  Suspected by cardiology to be malignant
   effusion. Felt not to be large enough for percutaneous drainage. EKG
   without signs of electrical alternans but does have low voltages.
   - F/u cardiology recs
   .
    # Sinus Pause on telemetry: Pt had episodes of sinus pauses on tele
   night of [**8-30**] without any since.  Cardiology consult thinks it
   vagally mediated.  Pauses decreased in frequency and duration on their
   own without intervention.
   - continue to hold metoprolol
   - as per cardiology, no need for transcutaneous pacing
   - monitor vitals, HR, hemodynamic instability, if resumed beat is wide
   complex; dopamine will be pressor of choice
   - no urgent need for echo, but get one before pt is discharged from
   hospital
   .
   #. Leukocytosis:  WBC trending downwards possibly due to 2 cycles
   chemotherapy. Pt most likely with VAP but leukopenia in setting of
   infection is also concerning.  [**Month (only) 11**] have also been due to inflammatory
   response given malignancy and SVC syndrome and is decreasing as they
   are treated.
   - Monitor blood, urine, sputum, thoracentesis cultures
   -Trend WBC
   - continue neupogen for 10 day course
   .
   #. Anemia:  Normocytic. Hct stable. Most acute concern would be DIC;
   LDH elevated although bilirubin normal. Haptoglobin normal. ACD
   possible given malignancy.
   - Trend hematocrit
   .
   #. s/p cerebral aneurysm repair:  Unclear why patient is disposed to
   having cerebral aneurysm. Pt mental status difficult to assess. She has
   a number of chronic changes on head CT.
   -continue antiepileptics.
   -f/u repeat head CT read
   .
   #. Hypertension: Metoprolol d/c
d held in setting of pauses given
   concern for beta blocker toxicity. Pt remains hypertensive.
   -Continue holding metoprolol
   -Hydralazine PRN to keep SBP 140s-160s.
   -Monitor propofol and BP carefully when giving hydralazine to avoid
   hypotensive episodes
   ICU Care

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 58-year-old female with a history of small cell carcinoma of the lung. She has been admitted to the ICU for radiation decompression therapy and chemotherapy. The patient's current condition includes hypoxic respiratory failure, altered mental status, acute renal failure, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis, superior vena cava syndrome, pleural effusion, pneumothorax, pericardial effusion, sinus pause on telemetry, leukocytosis, anemia, and hypertension.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxic respiratory failure: The patient continues to have mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis despite increasing respiratory rate. Peak pressures are high, and plate pressures are also elevated. The patient's oxygenation worsened last night, with saturation decreasing to 91%. PEEP was increased to address this issue. Underlying COPD, possible air stacking/trapping, possible ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), atelectasis/consolidation seen at bilateral bases, and potential pneumothorax are potential complications.

2. Altered mental status: The patient has been off propofol for almost 24 hours and continues not to follow commands. She withdraws from noxious stimuli but cannot cooperate for a neurologic exam. Differential includes seizure (given history), toxic metabolic, infection, and progression of cancer. A repeat head CT is planned today to evaluate for any changes, and an EEG will be performed to evaluate

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 58-year-old male with a new diagnosis of small cell carcinoma and superior vena cava (SVC) syndrome. He is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) due to respiratory failure caused by malpositioning/migration of the endotracheal tube (ETT) between the stent and tracheal wall, underlying extrinsic and intrinsic narrowing of the distal trachea and bronchi on the right, and background chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). The patient also has pulmonary infiltrates in the right lower lobe (RLL) attributed to ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), left lower lobe (LLL) infiltrate that resolved overnight, and evidence of sepsis with systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS). He is being treated with antibiotics for VAP and receiving mechanical ventilation. The patient has a history of seizure disorder and is currently off propofol. Repeat head CT scan was unrevealing for new pathology, and an MRI is not possible due to the presence of intracranial surgical clips. A lumbar puncture for cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis is planned to evaluate for carcinomatous meningitis. There is also concern for toxic-metabolic encephalopathy. The patient's SVC syndrome has improved over the past 48 hours, and he has completed chemotherapy. He is scheduled to undergo radiation therapy (XRT). The patient's small cell cancer

   58 yof with new diagnosis of small cell carcinoma  with SVC syndrome
   (partial compression), airway compromise (requiring Y-stent).
   RESPIRATORY FAILURE
 multifactorial, malpositioning/migration of ETT
   between stent and tracheal wall.  Also underlying extrinsic and
   intrinsic narrowing of distal trachea and bronchi on the right, on
   background of COPD(?).  Also evidence for new RLL and LLL
   (retrocardiac) infiltrates, concerning for pneumonai (VAP) -->
   empirical antimicrobials.  Continue mechanical ventilation, montior
   ABG.  Monitor sputum, await culture.  Hope to eventually work towards
   SBT and extubation once completes VAP treatment and completes chemoRx
   and XRT.
   PULMONARY INFILTRATES -- RLL  --> attributed to VAP.  Now on
   antimicrobials.  Monitor.  LLL infiltrate resolved over past 24 hrs,
   suspect related to mucus plug and /or atalectasis.
   MENTAL STATUS
 very slow to awken, now off Propofol >24 hrs.  Repeat
   head CT unrevealing for new pathology.  MRI not possible due to
   presence of intracranial surgical clips.  Underlying seizure disorder
   (on kepra) --> Plan EEG (continuous) to assess for non-convulsive
   status epilepticus.  LP for CSF analysis (concern for carcinomatous
   meningitis).  Consider Neurological Consultation.  [**Month (only) 11**] be toxic
   metabolic.
   SVC SYNDROME -- much improved over past 48 hrs.  Completed
   chemotherapy, continue XRT.
   SMALL CELL CA -- demonstating clinical response to XRT and
   chemotherapy.   Radiation Oncology and Oncology services involve
   appreciate recommendations and guidance.  Monitor for tumor lysis.
   Need to better define prognosis.
   RIGHT PLEURAL EFFUSION -- resolved, s/p chest tube drainage.
   Malignant.  Chest tube now removed.
   RIGHT PNEUMOTHORAX -- chest tube remains in place, lung fully
   expanded.  No evidence for air leak.
   PERICARDIAL EFFUSION -- no evidence of tamponade on exam
 continue to
   monitor.
   HYPONATREMIA -- improved.  Attributed to adrenal insufficiency,
   hypaldosteronism, SIADH --> possibly a mixture.  Continue steroids.
   HYPERTENSION
 monitor BP.  Maintain SBP 140-160 mmHg
   FLUIDS -- positive fluid balance, likely related to chemotherapy
   agents.  However, appears pre-renal --> continue net hydration.
   Monitor I/O.
   RENAL FAILURE -- rising creatinine, falling urine output.  Possible
   pre-renal, possibly related to chemotherapy and recent contrast dye.
   Monitor urine output, BUN, creatinine.
   METABOLIC ACIDOSIS  -- persistent, positive anion gap
 attributed to
   acute renal failure and ATN.  Continue to monitor.
   SEIZURE DISORDER -- continue kepra.  EEG to assess for non-convulsive

   SINUS DYSRHYTHMIA
 sinus pauses, no hemodynamic compromise.  Possible
   related to hilar mass, possible invovlement of conduction system.
   Possible vagal tone.  Monitor electrolytes.  Hold beta-blocker.

   for specific intervention.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient's chief complaint is respiratory failure. The patient remains intubated and mechanically ventilated, with intermittent follow-up of simple commands. 

The patient has a history of small cell carcinoma with superior vena cava (SVC) syndrome, airway compromise requiring Y-stent placement, and recent right lower lobe (RLL) and left lower lobe (LLL) infiltrates concerning for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). The patient has been started on empirical antimicrobials and is being monitored closely.

The patient's mental status is described as very slow to awaken, now off Propofol for over 24 hours. A repeat head CT showed no new pathology, and an MRI cannot be performed due to the presence of intracranial surgical clips. Continuous EEG is planned to assess for non-convulsive status epilepticus, and a lumbar puncture for cerebrospinal fluid analysis is being considered to evaluate for carcinomatous meningitis. Neurological consultation is also being sought.

The patient's SVC syndrome has improved over the past 48 hours, and chemotherapy has been completed. Radiation oncology and oncology services are involved, and the patient's response to radiation therapy and chemotherapy is being monitored. The patient is also at risk for tumor lysis syndrome.

The patient previously had a right pleural effusion, which has resolved after chest tube drainage and was found to be malignant. A right pneumothor

 RENAL FAILURE, ACUTE (ACUTE RENAL FAILURE, ARF)

   58F with likely small cell carcinoma complicated by SVC syndrome,
   airway compromise requiring Y-stent, pericardial effusion, resolved
   pleural effusion and pneumothorax, and electrolytes disturbances
   admitted to [**Hospital Unit Name 10**] for radiation decompression therapy and chemotherapy.
   .
   #. Hypoxic respiratory failure:  Pt had transient hypoxia with skin
   mottling yesterday afternoon and bronch revealed ETT lodged between
   tracheal wall and Y stent.  ETT was repositioned and hypoxia improved
   although pt was still autoPEEPing.  This AM her RR was decreased as she
   was breathing over it.  Respiratory status also complicated by possible
   underlying COPD given smoking history with possible air
   stacking/trapping, possible VAP or other pulmonary infection,
   atelectasis/consolidation seen at bilateral bases.  PTX not seen on
   CXR.
   - holding vanc as her level is elevated; will check level in AM and
   readjust dose as needed
   - continue cefepime and Cipro to cover MRSA and pseudomonas VAP
   - wean ventilator as tolerated, likely to stay on AC today
   - plan to titrate down propofol and trial of fentanyl for pain
   management
   - chest tube to stay in place as per IP recs until patient is off vent
   - s/p 3 days of chemotherapy
   - f/u speciation of sputum cx
   .
   # Altered Mental Status: Patient has been off propofol and still not
   moving extremities or grossly following commands.  She does withdraw
   from noxious stimuli but cannot cooperate for neuro exam.  Differential
   includes seizure (given hx), toxic metabolic, Infection, progression of
   cancer.  Repeat CT head unchanged from prior.  EEG today to eval for
   possible non-convulsive seizure activity.  Also plan for LP to eval for
   possible leptomeningeal spread of her cancer.
   - f/u EEG (with plans to consult neuro if abnormal)
   -f/u head CT read
   - LP and will send CSF sent for cytology and cx
   .
   #. Small cell lung carcinoma: per pathology, the tumor probably fits
   into the spectrum of a small cell carcinoma of lung. Given associated
   SVC syndrome, prognosis is likely poor. CT [**Last Name (un) **]/pelvis/head negative
   for metastases.  s/p 3 days of chemo and 2 sessions of XRT.  Initially,
   XRT was clinical emergency - they might've treated lots of nl tissue;
   needs formal tissue planning session to reduce amount they radiate;
   will wait until new scans/doing clinically better.  Rad/onc to do
   formal planning session next Tues or so to let chemo work for a bit
   Per heme/onc, it will be a few weeks before next round of chemo.
   - continue neupogen for 10 day course
   - f/u heme/onc recs
   - start neutropenic precautions
   .
   # Acute Renal failure: In setting of chemo with carboplatin.  Renal
   spun urine yesterday and casts consistent with ATN.  Plan to optimize
   SBP 120s-130s, consider pRBCs to keep increased intravascular delivery
   to kidneys. Ordered renal US  for obstruction.
   - gently hydrate with IVFs
   - will check SvO2 to eval oxygenation and need for possible pRBC
   transfusion
   - trend Cr and renally dose meds
   - continue to hold vanc as level too elevated
   .
   #. Metabolic acidosis:  Realize this is now a gap metabolic acidosis as
   her albumin is low.  Her metabolic acidosis is likely related to
   uremia.  Goal pH is 7.3-7.35.
   - will f/u endo recs
   - f/u renal recs
   - started on Bicitra
   .
   #. Hyponatremia: Resolved.  Unclear etiology on admission- thought to
   be secondary to possible adrenal insufficency (now discarded) or
   possibly SIADH.  Low UNa does not exclude SIADH; renal recommends
   rechecking urine lytes with saline load.  (In SIADH, UNa should
   increase and Uosm should remain high).
   - f/u any endocrine and renal recs
   .
   # Hyperkalemia: Continues to have hyperkalemia without further episodes
   of sinus pauses on EKG.  [**Month (only) 11**] be due to hypoaldosteronism but unlikely
   per endocrine.  Etiology unclear. Not Type IV RTA b/c urine sodium not
   >30. Checking serum renin, aldosterone.  Could be hyperkalemia in the
   setting of cell death from chemo.
   -F/u Cardiology recs
   -F/u endocrinology recs
   - f/u renal recs
   - f/u renin, [**Male First Name (un) **]
   .
   #. SVC syndrome:  Incomplete occlusion of SVC; near complete occlusion
   of brachiocephalic veins. Clinically identified by upper extremity and
   facial swelling/plethora and mottled skin. Also with scleral edema.
   Unable to assess jugular venous distension given considerable swelling.
   Seen in appoximately 10% cases of SSLC. Improved edema on exam compared
   to admission.
   - Radiation therapy and chemotherapy for decompression
   .
   #. Pleural effusion:  s/p right pigtail catheter placement [**2172-8-25**],
   removed [**2172-8-31**]. LDH effusion/serum 0.68 (exudate by Light
s criteria).
   Greatest concern for malignant effusion.  Cytology nonspecific.
   Cultures of fluid all preliminary negative.
   .
   #. Pneumothorax:  appears resolved on CXR.
   - Will keep tube in place most likely until pt extubated to prevent
   recurrence of pneumothorax with removal
   .
   #. Pericardial effusion:  Suspected by cardiology to be malignant
   effusion. Felt not to be large enough for percutaneous drainage. EKG
   without signs of electrical alternans but does have low voltages.
   - F/u cardiology recs
   .
    # Sinus Pause on telemetry: Pt had episodes of sinus pauses on tele
   night of [**8-30**] without any since.  Cardiology consult thinks it
   vagally mediated.  Pauses decreased in frequency and duration on their
   own without intervention.
   - continue to hold metoprolol
   - as per cardiology, no need for transcutaneous pacing
   - monitor vitals, HR, hemodynamic instability, if resumed beat is wide
   complex; dopamine will be pressor of choice
   - no urgent need for echo, but get one before pt is discharged from
   hospital
   .
   #. Leukocytosis:  WBC trending downwards possibly due to 3 days of
   chemotherapy. Pt most likely with VAP but leukopenia in setting of
   infection is also concerning.  [**Month (only) 11**] have also been due to inflammatory
   response given malignancy and SVC syndrome and is decreasing as they
   are treated.
   - Monitor blood, urine, sputum, thoracentesis cultures
   -Trend WBC
   - continue neupogen for 10 day course
   .
   #. Anemia:  Normocytic. Hct stable. Most acute concern would be DIC;
   LDH elevated although bilirubin normal. Haptoglobin normal. ACD
   possible given malignancy.
   - Trend hematocrit
   .
   #. s/p cerebral aneurysm repair:  Unclear why patient is disposed to
   having cerebral aneurysm. Pt mental status difficult to assess. She has
   a number of chronic changes on head CT.
   -continue antiepileptics.
   -f/u repeat head CT read
   .
   #. Hypertension: Metoprolol d/c
d held in setting of pauses given
   concern for beta blocker toxicity. Pt remains hypertensive.
   -Continue holding metoprolol
   -Hydralazine PRN to keep SBP 140s-160s.
   -Monitor propofol and BP carefully when giving hydralazine to avoid
   hypotensive episodes

An EEG is pending to evaluate for possible non-convulsive seizure activity, and a lumbar puncture has been done to evaluate for leptomeningeal spread of her cancer.

   .
   #. Hypoxic respiratory failure:  Pt had transient hypoxia with skin

   tracheal wall and Y stent.  ETT was repositioned and hypoxia improved
   although pt was still autoPEEPing.  This AM her RR was decreased as she
   was breathing over it.  Respiratory status also complicated by possible
   underlying COPD given smoking history with possible air
   stacking/trapping, possible VAP or other pulmonary infection,
   atelectasis/consolidation seen at bilateral bases.  PTX not seen on
   CXR.
   - holding vanc as her level is elevated; will check level in AM and
   readjust dose as needed
   - continue cefepime and Cipro to cover MRSA and pseudomonas VAP
   - wean ventilator as tolerated, likely to stay on AC today
   - plan to titrate down propofol and trial of fentanyl for pain
   management
   - chest tube to stay in place as per IP recs until patient is off vent
   - s/p 3 days of chemotherapy
   - f/u speciation of sputum cx
   .
   # Altered Mental Status: Patient has been off propofol and still not
   moving extremities or grossly following commands.  She does withdraw
   from noxious stimuli but cannot cooperate for neuro exam.  Differential
   includes seizure (given hx), toxic metabolic, Infection, progression of
   cancer.  Repeat CT head unchanged from prior.  EEG today to eval for
   possible non-convulsive seizure activity.  Also plan for LP to eval for
   possible leptomeningeal spread of her cancer.
   - f/u EEG (with plans to consult neuro if abnormal)
   -f/u head CT read
   - LP and will send CSF sent for cytology and cx
   .
   #. Small cell lung carcinoma: per pathology, the tumor probably fits
   into the spectrum of a small cell carcinoma of lung. Given associated
   SVC syndrome, prognosis is likely poor. CT [**Last Name (un) **]/pelvis/head negative
   for metastases.  s/p 3 days of chemo and 2 sessions of XRT.  Initially,
   XRT was clinical emergency - they might've treated lots of nl tissue;
   needs formal tissue planning session to reduce amount they radiate;
   will wait until new scans/doing clinically better.  Rad/onc to do
   formal planning session next Tues or so to let chemo work for a bit
   Per heme/onc, it will be a few weeks before next round of chemo.
   - continue neupogen for 10 day course
   - f/u heme/onc recs
   - start neutropenic precautions
   .
   # Acute Renal failure: In setting of chemo with carboplatin.  Renal
   spun urine yesterday and casts consistent with ATN.  Plan to optimize
   SBP 120s-130s, consider pRBCs to keep increased intravascular delivery
   to kidneys. Ordered renal US  for obstruction.
   - gently hydrate with IVFs
   - will check SvO2 to eval oxygenation and need for possible pRBC
   transfusion
   - trend Cr and renally dose meds
   - continue to hold vanc as level too elevated
   .

   - will f/u endo recs
   - f/u renal recs
   - started on Bicitra
   .

   be secondary to possible adrenal insufficency (now discarded) or
   possibly SIADH.  Low UNa does not exclude SIADH; renal recommends
   rechecking urine lytes with saline load.  (In SIADH, UNa should
   increase and Uosm should remain high).
   - f/u any endocrine and renal recs
   .

   of sinus pauses on EKG.  [**Month (only) 11**] be due to hypoaldosteronism but unlikely

   setting of cell death from chemo.
   -F/u Cardiology recs

   - f/u renal recs
   - f/u renin, [**Male First Name (un) **]
   .

   of brachiocephalic veins. Clinically identified by upper extremity and
   facial swelling/plethora and mottled skin. Also with scleral edema.

s criteria).

   .
   #. Pericardial effusion:  Suspected by cardiology to be malignant
   effusion. Felt not to be large enough for percutaneous drainage. EKG
   without signs of electrical alternans but does have low voltages.
   - F/u cardiology recs

   vagally mediated.  Pauses decreased in frequency and duration on their

   chemotherapy. Pt most likely with VAP but leukopenia in setting of
   infection is also concerning.  [**Month (only) 11**] have also been due to inflammatory
   response given malignancy and SVC syndrome and is decreasing as they

   - Monitor blood, urine, sputum, thoracentesis cultures

   .

Summary:
The patient is a 58-year-old female with a history of small cell carcinoma of the lung, complicated by superior vena cava (SVC) syndrome, airway compromise requiring Y-stent placement, pericardial effusion, resolved pleural effusion, and electrolyte disturbances. She is currently admitted to the ICU for radiation decompression therapy and chemotherapy.

The patient's current condition includes hypoxic respiratory failure, altered mental status, tachycardia, acute respiratory failure (not ARDS), adrenal insufficiency, airway obstruction, central/upper, and electrolyte & fluid disorder.

The patient's medical complications include:

1. Hypoxic respiratory failure: The patient had transient hypoxia with skin mottling yesterday afternoon, and an endotracheal tube (ETT) was lodged between the tracheal wall and Y-stent. The ETT was repositioned, and hypoxia improved, although the patient is still autoPEEPing. This morning, her respiratory rate decreased as she was breathing over it. The patient's respiratory status is also complicated by possible underlying chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) given her smoking history with possible air stacking/trapping, possible ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) or other pulmonary infection, atelectasis/consolidation seen at bilateral bases. The chest tube will stay in place as per interventional procedure recommendations until the patient is off the ventilator.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old male with a new diagnosis of small cell carcinoma and superior vena cava (SVC) syndrome. He is currently intubated and mechanically ventilated in the ICU due to respiratory failure. The patient has been treated with chemotherapy and radiation therapy for his cancer.

The patient's current conditions include pulmonary infiltrates on the right lower lobe (RLL), which are attributed to ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP); left lower lobe (LLL) infiltrate that resolved over the past 24 hours; mental status changes; SVC syndrome; neutropenia; renal failure with acute tubular necrosis (ATN); right pleural effusion, which has resolved; right pneumothorax; pericardial effusion without evidence of tamponade; hypertension; positive fluid balance likely related to chemotherapy agents; metabolic acidosis with an anion gap; seizure disorder; sinus dysrhythmia; and anemia.

The patient is receiving nutritional support through tube feeding, and his glycemic control is being monitored. Prophylactic measures include stress ulcer prophylaxis, deep vein thrombosis (DVT) prophylaxis, and elevation of head of bed (HOB) to prevent ventilator-associated pneumonia.

The patient's code status is full code, and his disposition is in the ICU. The attending physician spent a total of 45 minutes with the patient. The patient is critically ill, and

Summary:
Based on the information provided in the progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old male with a new diagnosis of small cell carcinoma of the lung and superior vena cava (SVC) syndrome. The patient has respiratory failure due to malpositioning/migration of the endotracheal tube (ETT), underlying extrinsic and intrinsic narrowing of the distal trachea and bronchi on the right, on the background of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). There are also new right lower lobe (RLL) and left lower lobe (LLL) infiltrates, concerning for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). 

The patient has mental status changes, which are very slow to awaken and now off propofol for over 24 hours. A repeat head CT scan was unrevealing for new pathology. An MRI is not possible due to the presence of intracranial surgical clips. There is an underlying seizure disorder, but no evidence for carcinomatous meningitis by lumbar puncture. An EEG is pending for seizure disorder assessment. 

The patient has shown improvement in SVC syndrome over the past 48 hours, after completing chemotherapy and continuing radiation therapy. The small cell cancer is demonstrating a clinical response to X-ray therapy and chemotherapy. 

Other complications include neutropenia, renal failure with muddy brown casts on urinalysis indicating acute tubular necrosis (ATN), right pleural effusion that has resolved after chest tube drainage,

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 58-year-old male with a new diagnosis of small cell carcinoma and superior vena cava (SVC) syndrome. He is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) and is experiencing respiratory failure due to malpositioning/migration of endotracheal tube (ETT), underlying extrinsic and intrinsic narrowing of the distal trachea and bronchi on the right, and new right lower lobe (RLL) and left lower lobe (LLL) infiltrates, which are concerning for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation and empirical antimicrobials for VAP. His mental status is very slow to awaken, possibly due to a toxic-metabolic encephalopathy. An MRI is not possible due to the presence of intracranial surgical clips, and an EEG is pending to evaluate for non-convulsive status. The patient has completed chemotherapy and radiation therapy, showing clinical response to treatment. He also has a history of seizure disorder and right-sided pleural effusion, pneumothorax, pericardial effusion, hypertension, positive fluid balance, metabolic acidosis, and sinus dysrhythmia. The patient's nutritional support includes enteral feeding through a feeding tube (TF).

Summary:
The patient is a 58-year-old female with a history of small cell carcinoma of the lung, complicated by superior vena cava (SVC) syndrome, airway compromise requiring Y-stent placement, pericardial effusion, resolved pleural effusion, and pneumothorax. The patient was admitted for radiation decompression therapy and chemotherapy. She is now experiencing hypoxic respiratory failure, renal failure, and altered mental status.

The patient's current condition includes:

1. Hypoxic respiratory failure: The patient desaturated yesterday, and bronchoscopy revealed that the endotracheal tube (ETT) was displaced between the stent and tracheal wall. The ETT was repositioned, but the patient still has a leak due to its high position over the stent. Increasing tidal volume worsens the leak. The patient is acidotic with a respiratory rate of 28, and there is little room to increase the respiratory rate. The respiratory status is also complicated by possible underlying chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), possible ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), and atelectasis/consolidation seen at bilateral bases. Pneumothorax is not seen on the chest X-ray (CXR), but bilateral pleural effusions are seen on computed tomography (CT). The tumor has decreased in size. 

- Hold vancomycin as the level is elevated.
- Continue cefepime and Cipro to cover MRSA

   Assessment and Plan
   58F with likely small cell carcinoma complicated by SVC syndrome,
   airway compromise requiring Y-stent, pericardial effusion, resolved
   pleural effusion and pneumothorax, and electrolytes disturbances
   admitted to [**Hospital Unit Name 10**] for radiation decompression therapy and chemotherapy.
   .
   #. Hypoxic respiratory failure:  Pt had transient hypoxia with skin
   mottling yesterday afternoon and bronch revealed ETT lodged between
   tracheal wall and Y stent.  ETT was repositioned and hypoxia improved
   although pt was still autoPEEPing.  This AM her RR was decreased as she
   was breathing over it.  Respiratory status also complicated by possible
   underlying COPD given smoking history with possible air
   stacking/trapping, possible VAP or other pulmonary infection,
   atelectasis/consolidation seen at bilateral bases.  PTX not seen on
   CXR.
   - holding vanc as her level is elevated; will check level in AM and
   readjust dose as needed
   - continue cefepime and Cipro to cover MRSA and pseudomonas VAP
   - wean ventilator as tolerated, likely to stay on AC today
   - plan to titrate down propofol and trial of fentanyl for pain
   management
   - chest tube to stay in place as per IP recs until patient is off vent
   - s/p 3 days of chemotherapy
   - f/u speciation of sputum cx
   .
   # Altered Mental Status: Patient has been off propofol and still not
   moving extremities or grossly following commands.  She does withdraw
   from noxious stimuli but cannot cooperate for neuro exam.  Differential
   includes seizure (given hx), toxic metabolic, Infection, progression of
   cancer.  Repeat CT head unchanged from prior.  EEG today to eval for
   possible non-convulsive seizure activity.  Also plan for LP to eval for
   possible leptomeningeal spread of her cancer.
   - f/u EEG (with plans to consult neuro if abnormal)
   -f/u head CT read
   - LP and will send CSF sent for cytology and cx
   .
   #. Small cell lung carcinoma: per pathology, the tumor probably fits
   into the spectrum of a small cell carcinoma of lung. Given associated
   SVC syndrome, prognosis is likely poor. CT [**Last Name (un) **]/pelvis/head negative
   for metastases.  s/p 3 days of chemo and 2 sessions of XRT.  Initially,
   XRT was clinical emergency - they might've treated lots of nl tissue;
   needs formal tissue planning session to reduce amount they radiate;
   will wait until new scans/doing clinically better.  Rad/onc to do
   formal planning session next Tues or so to let chemo work for a bit
   Per heme/onc, it will be a few weeks before next round of chemo.
   - continue neupogen for 10 day course
   - f/u heme/onc recs
   - start neutropenic precautions
   .
   # Acute Renal failure: In setting of chemo with carboplatin.  Renal
   spun urine yesterday and casts consistent with ATN.  Plan to optimize
   SBP 120s-130s, consider pRBCs to keep increased intravascular delivery
   to kidneys. Ordered renal US  for obstruction.
   - gently hydrate with IVFs
   - will check SvO2 to eval oxygenation and need for possible pRBC
   transfusion
   - trend Cr and renally dose meds
   - continue to hold vanc as level too elevated
   .
   #. Metabolic acidosis:  Realize this is now a gap metabolic acidosis as
   her albumin is low.  Her metabolic acidosis is likely related to
   uremia.  Goal pH is 7.3-7.35.
   - will f/u endo recs
   - f/u renal recs
   - started on Bicitra
   .
   #. Hyponatremia: Resolved.  Unclear etiology on admission- thought to
   be secondary to possible adrenal insufficency (now discarded) or
   possibly SIADH.  Low UNa does not exclude SIADH; renal recommends
   rechecking urine lytes with saline load.  (In SIADH, UNa should
   increase and Uosm should remain high).
   - f/u any endocrine and renal recs
   .
   # Hyperkalemia: Continues to have hyperkalemia without further episodes
   of sinus pauses on EKG.  [**Month (only) 11**] be due to hypoaldosteronism but unlikely
   per endocrine.  Etiology unclear. Not Type IV RTA b/c urine sodium not
   >30. Checking serum renin, aldosterone.  Could be hyperkalemia in the
   setting of cell death from chemo.
   -F/u Cardiology recs
   -F/u endocrinology recs
   - f/u renal recs
   - f/u renin, [**Male First Name (un) **]
   .
   #. SVC syndrome:  Incomplete occlusion of SVC; near complete occlusion
   of brachiocephalic veins. Clinically identified by upper extremity and
   facial swelling/plethora and mottled skin. Also with scleral edema.
   Unable to assess jugular venous distension given considerable swelling.
   Seen in appoximately 10% cases of SSLC. Improved edema on exam compared
   to admission.
   - Radiation therapy and chemotherapy for decompression
   .
   #. Pleural effusion:  s/p right pigtail catheter placement [**2172-8-25**],
   removed [**2172-8-31**]. LDH effusion/serum 0.68 (exudate by Light
s criteria).
   Greatest concern for malignant effusion.  Cytology nonspecific.
   Cultures of fluid all preliminary negative.
   .
   #. Pneumothorax:  appears resolved on CXR.
   - Will keep tube in place most likely until pt extubated to prevent
   recurrence of pneumothorax with removal
   .
   #. Pericardial effusion:  Suspected by cardiology to be malignant
   effusion. Felt not to be large enough for percutaneous drainage. EKG
   without signs of electrical alternans but does have low voltages.
   - F/u cardiology recs
   .
    # Sinus Pause on telemetry: Pt had episodes of sinus pauses on tele
   night of [**8-30**] without any since.  Cardiology consult thinks it
   vagally mediated.  Pauses decreased in frequency and duration on their
   own without intervention.
   - continue to hold metoprolol
   - as per cardiology, no need for transcutaneous pacing
   - monitor vitals, HR, hemodynamic instability, if resumed beat is wide
   complex; dopamine will be pressor of choice
   - no urgent need for echo, but get one before pt is discharged from
   hospital
   .
   #. Leukocytosis:  WBC trending downwards possibly due to 3 days of
   chemotherapy. Pt most likely with VAP but leukopenia in setting of
   infection is also concerning.  [**Month (only) 11**] have also been due to inflammatory
   response given malignancy and SVC syndrome and is decreasing as they
   are treated.
   - Monitor blood, urine, sputum, thoracentesis cultures
   -Trend WBC
   - continue neupogen for 10 day course
   .
   #. Anemia:  Normocytic. Hct stable. Most acute concern would be DIC;
   LDH elevated although bilirubin normal. Haptoglobin normal. ACD
   possible given malignancy.
   - Trend hematocrit
   .
   #. s/p cerebral aneurysm repair:  Unclear why patient is disposed to
   having cerebral aneurysm. Pt mental status difficult to assess. She has
   a number of chronic changes on head CT.
   -continue antiepileptics.
   -f/u repeat head CT read
   .
   #. Hypertension: Metoprolol d/c
d held in setting of pauses given
   concern for beta blocker toxicity. Pt remains hypertensive.
   -Continue holding metoprolol
   -Hydralazine PRN to keep SBP 140s-160s.
   -Monitor propofol and BP carefully when giving hydralazine to avoid
   hypotensive episodes

Summary:
The patient is a 58-year-old individual with a new diagnosis of small cell carcinoma, presenting with superior vena cava (SVC) syndrome, airway compromise requiring Y-stent placement, and pneumothorax. The patient was admitted for radiation therapy and chemotherapy. The patient's respiratory failure is multifactorial, including malpositioning/migration of endotracheal tube (ETT), underlying extrinsic and intrinsic narrowing of the distal trachea and bronchi, probable chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and evidence for new right lower lobe (RLL) and left lower lobe (LLL) infiltrates, concerning for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). The patient is currently on broad-spectrum antimicrobials, mechanical ventilation, and continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT).

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is complex and multifactorial. The airway compromise due to the migration of ETT between the stent and tracheal wall, underlying extrinsic and intrinsic narrowing of the distal trachea and bronchi, probable COPD, and new LLL infiltrate attributed to VAP pose significant challenges. Continuous monitoring and optimization of mechanical ventilation, along with appropriate antibiotic therapy, are essential.

2. Pneumonia: The presence of new RLL and LLL infiltrates raises concerns for pneumonia. Continued surveillance of sputum and follow-up chest X-ray

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 58-year-old female with respiratory failure due to small cell lung cancer, airway collapse, right effusion, SVC syndrome, right pneumonia, altered mental status, tachycardia, hypotension, acute renal failure, thrombocytopenia, and hypernatremia. The patient's respiratory failure is multifactorial, including malpositioning/migration of ETT between stent and tracheal wall, extrinsic and intrinsic narrowing of distal trachea and bronchi, lung mass, probable underlying COPD, and right lower lobe infiltrates concerning for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). The patient is on broad-spectrum antibiotics and continues to be supported with assisted controlled ventilation.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Tension pneumothorax: The patient has a history of airway collapse and right pneumonia, which increases the risk of tension pneumothorax.
2. Pericardial effusion/tamponade: The patient's tachycardia and hypotension may be indicative of cardiac tamponade, especially considering the presence of a pericardial effusion.
3. Pulmonary embolism (PE): The patient's tachycardia and hypotension could also be due to a PE, particularly given the immobilization and malignancy.
4. Infection: The patient is on broad-spectrum antibiotics for suspected VAP. However, there

   Assessment and Plan
   58F with likely small cell carcinoma complicated by SVC syndrome,
   airway compromise requiring Y-stent, pericardial effusion, resolved
   pleural effusion and pneumothorax, admitted to [**Hospital Unit Name 10**] for radiation
   decompression therapy and chemotherapy, now with respiratory failure,
   renal failure and altered mental status.
   .
   #. Hypoxic respiratory failure:  Pt still acidotic with RR 28
 little
   room to increase RR. Numerous changes made to ventilator and tube
   placement yesterday.  Respiratory status also complicated by possible
   underlying COPD given smoking history with possible air
   stacking/trapping, possible VAP or other pulmonary infection,
   atelectasis/consolidation seen at bilateral bases.  PTX not seen on
   CXR. Also with b/l pleural effusions seen on CT although tumor has
   decreased.
   - holding vanc as her level is elevated (therapeutic today); will check
   level in AM and readjust dose as needed
 continue holding today (d1 =
   [**2172-8-31**]; 8 day course)
   - continue cefepime and Cipro to cover MRSA and pseudomonas VAP
   - wean ventilator as tolerated, likely to stay on AC today
   - chest tube to stay in place as per IP recs until patient is off vent
   - s/p 3 days of chemotherapy; scheduled for formal planning for XRT
   early next week (approx [**2172-9-8**])
   - f/u speciation of sputum cx
   .
   # Altered Mental Status: Patient has been off propofol >48h and still
   not moving extremities or grossly following commands. Most likley toxic
   metabolic encephalopathy as pt is uremic. Differential includes seizure
   although EEG does not demonstrate seizure activity. LP does not
   demonstrate infection or spread of malignancy. CT head negative for
   acute process.
   - f/u  CSF studies
   - Consider neuro consult
   .
   # Acute Renal failure: In setting of chemo with carboplatin.  Urine
   casts consistent with ATN.  Plan to optimize SBP 120s-130s.- - gently
   hydrate with IVFs
   - trend Cr and renally dose meds
   - continue to hold vanc as level too elevated
   .
   #. Metabolic acidosis:  Realize this is now a gap metabolic acidosis as
   her albumin is low.  Her metabolic acidosis is likely related to
   uremia.  Unable to increase RR due to concern for autopeeping in
   setting of possible COPD. Goal pH is 7.3-7.35.
   - will f/u endo and renal recs
   - continue on Bicitra
   - If pH continues to decrease below 7.2, will need bicarb
   .
   # Tachycardia/Hypotension
 Pt with continued tachycardia and episodes
   of hypotension. DDx includes possible enlarging pericardial
   effusion/tamponade (pulsus not helpful in setting of intubation per
   earlier cardiology note), pneumothorax. Pt appears to be in A-fib on
   monitor but difficult to tell. PE likely given malignancy and prolonged
   bed rest but unable to do CTA given renal failure and VQ scan not
   helpful in setting of lung changes.
   -CXR
   -EKG to evaluate for A-fib
   -Fluids to give preload for hypotensive episodes
   -Cardiology consult for STAT echo
   -LENI
s as unable to directly assess for PE
   -t/b with Hem/Onc re: anti-coagulation given tumor treatment
   .
   #. Electrolyte disturbances: Pt now with hypernatremia most likley due
   to dehydration with free water deficit of 1.4L, started on D5W
   overnight. Pt had hyponatremia and hyperkalemia on admission, both
   resolved. Unclear etiology of electrolyte disturbances on admission-
   thought to be secondary to possible adrenal insufficency (now
   discarded) or possibly SIADH.  Low UNa does not exclude SIADH; renal
   recommends rechecking urine lytes with saline load, not yet done in
   setting of pt
s other medical issues.  (In SIADH, UNa should increase
   and Uosm should remain high).
   - f/u any endocrine and renal recs
   -F/[**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) **] and renin
   .
   #. Small cell lung carcinoma: per pathology, the tumor probably fits
   into the spectrum of a small cell carcinoma of lung. Given associated
   SVC syndrome, prognosis is likely poor. CT [**Last Name (un) **]/pelvis/head negative
   for metastases.  s/p 3 days of chemo and 2 sessions of XRT.  Initially,
   XRT was clinical emergency - they might've treated lots of nl tissue;
   needs formal tissue planning session to reduce amount they radiate;
   will wait until new scans/doing clinically better.  Rad/onc to do
   formal planning session next Tues or so to let chemo work for a bit
   Per heme/onc, it will be a few weeks before next round of chemo.
   - continue neupogen for 10 day course
 per Hem/Onc, decreased WBC ct
   in setting of neupogen does not bode well.
   - f/u heme/onc recs
   - continue neutropenic precautions
   .
   #. SVC syndrome:  Incomplete occlusion of SVC; near complete occlusion
   of brachiocephalic veins. Clinically identified by upper extremity and
   facial swelling/plethora and mottled skin. Also with scleral edema.
   Unable to assess jugular venous distension given considerable swelling.
   Seen in appoximately 10% cases of SSLC. Improved edema on exam compared
   to admission. Per family, pt did not have SVC syndrome when she came to
   hospital ([**Hospital Unit Name 10**] team thought she had it on presentation to ED). SVC
   syndrome occurred after Y-stent placed. Possible that tumor pushing
   into trachea shifted to compress SVC after stent placement.
   - Radiation therapy and chemotherapy for decompression
   -F/u Hem/Onc recs
   .
   # Sinus Pause on telemetry: Pt had episodes of sinus pauses on tele
   night of [**8-30**]. Had new episdoes, again with turning.  Cardiology
   consult thinks it
s vagally mediated.  Pauses decreased in frequency
   and duration on their own without intervention.
   - Care with turning patient
   - continue to hold metoprolol
   - Per cardiology, no need for transcutaneous pacing
   - monitor vitals, HR, hemodynamic instability, if resumed beat is wide
   complex; dopamine will be pressor of choice
   .
   #Leukopenia/thrombocytopenia
 most likely due to chemotherapy. Pt on
   neupogen with continued decreased counts. Per Onc, this does not bode
   well for prognosis. Low suspicion for HITT.
   -F/u hem/onc recs
   -Trend CBC
   .
   #. Pleural effusion:  s/p right pigtail catheter placement [**2172-8-25**],
   removed [**2172-8-31**]. LDH effusion/serum 0.68 (exudate by Light
s criteria).
   Greatest concern for malignant effusion.  Cytology nonspecific.
   Cultures of fluid all preliminary negative.
   .
   #. Pneumothorax:  appears resolved on CXR.
   - Will keep tube in place most likely until pt extubated to prevent
   recurrence of pneumothorax with removal
   .
   #. Pericardial effusion:  Suspected by cardiology to be malignant
   effusion. Felt not to be large enough for percutaneous drainage. EKG
   without signs of electrical alternans but does have low voltages.
   - F/u cardiology recs
   .
   #. Anemia:  Normocytic. Hct stable. Most acute concern would be DIC;
   LDH elevated although bilirubin normal. Haptoglobin normal. ACD
   possible given malignancy.
   - Trend hematocrit
   .
   #. s/p cerebral aneurysm repair:  Unclear why patient is disposed to
   having cerebral aneurysm. Pt mental status difficult to assess. She has
   a number of chronic changes on head CT.
   -continue antiepileptics.
   .
   #. Hypertension: Now hypotensive (see above). Metoprolol d/c
d held in
   setting of pauses given concern for beta blocker toxicity. -Continue
   holding metoprolol
   -D/c hydralazine as pt is hypotensive
   -Monitor propofol and BP carefully when giving hydralazine to avoid
   hypotensive episodes
   .
   #Goals of care: discuss with family that pt is in multisystem organ
   failure and prognosis is poor.

Summary:
The patient is a 58-year-old female with a history of small cell carcinoma of the lung, complicated by superior vena cava (SVC) syndrome, airway compromise requiring Y-stent placement, pericardial effusion, resolved pleural effusion and pneumothorax. The patient is currently admitted to the ICU for radiation decompression therapy and chemotherapy. She is now experiencing hypoxic respiratory failure, renal failure, and altered mental status.

The patient's respiratory status is complicated by possible underlying chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), air trapping, ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), and atelectasis/consolidation seen at bilateral bases. The patient also has bilateral pleural effusions seen on CT, although the tumor has decreased. The patient's chest tube will remain in place as per interventional pulmonology recommendations until the patient is off the ventilator.

The patient has altered mental status, most likely due to toxic metabolic encephalopathy as she is uremic. The differential includes seizure, although the electroencephalogram (EEG) does not demonstrate seizure activity. The lumbar puncture (LP) does not demonstrate infection or spread of malignancy. The head CT is negative for acute process.

The patient has acute renal failure in the setting of chemotherapy with carboplatin. Urine casts consistent with acute tubular necrosis (ATN) have been observed. The plan is to optimize systemic blood pressure (SBP)

   Assessment and Plan
   58F with likely small cell carcinoma complicated by SVC syndrome,
   airway compromise requiring Y-stent, pericardial effusion, resolved
   pleural effusion and pneumothorax, admitted to [**Hospital Unit Name 10**] for radiation
   decompression therapy and chemotherapy, now with respiratory failure,
   renal failure and altered mental status.
   .
   #. Hypoxic respiratory failure:  Pt still acidotic due to repiratory
   and metabolic acidosis, improved with HCO3 administration overnight.
   However pt with high RR requirement to compensate for acidosis with
   little room to increase RR. Numerous changes made to ventilator and
   tube placement yesterday.  Respiratory status also complicated by
   possible underlying COPD given smoking history with possible air
   stacking/trapping, possible VAP or other pulmonary infection, pulm
   edema as she required lots of fluids for hypotension,
   atelectasis/consolidation seen at bilateral bases.  PTX not seen on
   CXR. Also with b/l pleural effusions seen on CT although tumor has
   decreased.
   -Vent: decrease tidal volumes as PIP high
   -Decrease FiO2 as tolerated
   -ABG to reassess oxygenation on new vent settings; goal pH > 7.2
   (7.2-7.24) with goal PaO2 >60.
   - holding vanc (for MRSA) as her level is elevated (therapeutic today);
   will check level in AM and readjust dose as needed
 continue holding
   today (d1 = [**2172-8-31**]; 8 day course)
   - continue cefepime and Cipro to cover pseudomonas VAP (Day 1= [**2172-8-31**];
   8 day course)
   - chest tube to stay in place as per IP recs until patient is off vent
   - s/p 3 days of chemotherapy; scheduled for formal planning for XRT
   early next week (approx [**2172-9-8**])
   - f/u speciation of sputum cx; BAL results
   -bladder pressure [**Hospital1 **]
   -Possible bronch to evaluate tube placement
   -Goals of care (see below)
   .
   # Altered Mental Status: Patient has been off propofol >72h and still
   not moving extremities or grossly following commands. Most likley toxic
   metabolic encephalopathy as pt is uremic. Differential includes seizure
   although EEG does not demonstrate seizure activity. LP does not
   demonstrate infection or spread of malignancy. CT head negative for
   acute process.
   - f/u  CSF studies
   -Will defer neuro consult at this time as it will most likely not
   change management
   .
   # Acute Renal failure: Pt now anuric. In setting of chemo with
   carboplatin.  Urine casts consistent with ATN.  Plan to optimize SBP
   120s-130s but pt with hypotension. Now unable to give fluids as pt is
   volume overloaded, contributing to hypoxia.  Also, increased uric acid
   suggests possible TLS although usually seen 1-2d after chemo for SCC,
   here seen 4-5d post chemo.
   - trend Cr and renally dose meds
   - continue to hold vanc as level too elevated
   .
   #. Metabolic acidosis: Now with respiratory and metabolic acidosis.
   Received HCO3 last night so pH improved. Realize this is now a gap
   metabolic acidosis as her albumin is low.  Her metabolic acidosis is
   likely related to uremia.  Unable to increase RR due to concern for
   autopeeping in setting of possible COPD. Goal pH is 7.2-7.24.
   - will f/u endo and renal recs
   - If pH continues to decrease below 7.2, unable to give more HCO3 as it
   requires much fluid and pt is fluid overloaded.
   .
   # Tachycardia/Hypotension with new [**Name (NI) 7929**]
 Pt with continued
   tachycardia and episodes of hypotension. EKG demonstrated new onset
   A-fib. LENIs negative for DVT but unable to assess for PE as pt cannot
   have CTA given renal failure and VQ scan will not be helpful in setting
   of lung pathology. Echo did not show RV strain or enlarging pericardial
   effusion. Per Hem/Onc, no anti-coagulation as tumor may hemorrhage.
   Also may have increased SVC compression with decreased preload.
   -F/u Hem/Onc re: chemo and XRT (currently scheduled for approx [**2172-9-8**])
   -[**Month (only) 11**] do small fluid boluses for hypotension although pt with pulm edema
   until d/w family
   .
   #. Electrolyte disturbances: Hypernatremia resolved after D5W
   administration. Pt had hyponatremia and hyperkalemia on admission, both
   resolved. Unclear etiology of electrolyte disturbances on admission-
   thought to be secondary to possible adrenal insufficency (now
   discarded) or possibly SIADH.  Low UNa does not exclude SIADH; renal
   recommends rechecking urine lytes with saline load, not yet done in
   setting of pt
s other medical issues.  (In SIADH, UNa should increase
   and Uosm should remain high).
   - f/u any endocrine and renal recs
   -F/[**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) **] and renin
   .
   #. Small cell lung carcinoma: per pathology, the tumor probably fits
   into the spectrum of a small cell carcinoma of lung. Given associated
   SVC syndrome, prognosis is likely poor. CT [**Last Name (un) **]/pelvis/head negative
   for metastases.  s/p 3 days of chemo and 2 sessions of XRT.  Initially,
   XRT was clinical emergency - they might've treated lots of nl tissue;
   Pt was to have formal tissue planning session early this week (approx
   [**2172-9-8**]).
   - continue neupogen for 10 day course
 per Hem/Onc, decreased WBC ct
   in setting of neupogen does not bode well.
   - f/u heme/onc recs and rad/onc recs
   - continue neutropenic precautions
   .
   #. SVC syndrome:  Incomplete occlusion of SVC; near complete occlusion
   of brachiocephalic veins. Clinically identified by upper extremity and
   facial swelling/plethora and mottled skin. Seen in appoximately 10%
   cases of SSLC. Improved edema on exam compared to admission. Per
   family, pt did not have SVC syndrome when she came to hospital ([**Hospital Unit Name 10**]
   team thought she had it on presentation to ED). SVC syndrome occurred
   after Y-stent placed. Possible that tumor pushing into trachea shifted
   to compress SVC after stent placement.
   - Radiation therapy and chemotherapy for decompression
   -F/u Hem/Onc recs
   .
   # Sinus Pause on telemetry: Pt had episodes of sinus pauses on tele
   night of [**8-30**]. Had new episodes within last few days, again with
   turning.  Resumed beat is junctional. Cardiology consult thinks it
   vagally mediated.  Pauses decreased in frequency and duration on their
   own without intervention.
   - Care with turning patient
   - continue to hold metoprolol
   - Per cardiology, no need for transcutaneous pacing
   - monitor vitals, HR, hemodynamic instability, no pressors if resumed
   beat is wide complex.
   .
   #Leukopenia/thrombocytopenia
 most likely due to chemotherapy. Pt on
   neupogen with continued decreased counts. Per Onc, this does not bode
   well for prognosis. Low suspicion for HITT.
   -D/c heparin SC
   -F/u hem/onc recs
   -Trend CBC
   .
   #. Pleural effusion:  s/p right pigtail catheter placement [**2172-8-25**],
   removed [**2172-8-31**]. LDH effusion/serum 0.68 (exudate by Light
s criteria).
   Greatest concern for malignant effusion.  Cytology nonspecific.
   Cultures of fluid all preliminary negative.
   .
   #. Pneumothorax:  appears resolved on CXR.
   - Will keep tube in place most likely until pt extubated to prevent
   recurrence of pneumothorax with removal
   .
   #. Pericardial effusion:  Suspected by cardiology to be malignant
   effusion. Felt not to be large enough for percutaneous drainage. EKG
   without signs of electrical alternans but does have low voltages. Per
   ECHO [**2172-9-5**], effusion not increased. No tamponade.
   - F/u cardiology recs
   .
   #. Anemia:  Normocytic. Hct stable. Most acute concern would be DIC,
   but labs WNL. ACD possible given malignancy.
   - Trend hematocrit
   .
   #. s/p cerebral aneurysm repair:  Unclear why patient is disposed to
   having cerebral aneurysm. Pt mental status difficult to assess. She has
   a number of chronic changes on head CT.
   -continue antiepileptics.
   .
   #Goals of care: discuss with family that pt is in multisystem organ
   failure and prognosis is poor.
   -Palliative care consult

The patient is a 58-year-old female with a history of small cell carcinoma of the lung (SCC) who is currently in the ICU for respiratory failure, renal failure, and altered mental status. She has a complex medical history, including SVC syndrome, airway compromise requiring Y-stent placement, pericardial effusion, resolved pleural effusion and pneumothorax. The patient is also experiencing hypotension and tachycardia with new onset atrial fibrillation. She has leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, anemia, hypernatremia, hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis, and electrolyte disturbances.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is still acidotic due to respiratory and metabolic acidosis, and there is a concern for possible underlying COPD, air trapping, ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), or other pulmonary infections. The goal is to improve oxygenation and ventilation while avoiding further complications.

2. Renal Failure: The patient has anuria and is volume overloaded, which may contribute to hypoxia. There is a concern for acute tubular necrosis (ATN) and tumor lysis syndrome (TLS). Renal function should be closely monitored, and medications should be adjusted accordingly.

   58 yo f with respiratory failure in setting of newly diagnosed lung ca
   (likely small cell) c/b SVC syndrome (partial compression), airway
   compromise (requiring Y-stent) admitted for xrt and chemotherapy now
   with progressive clinical decline and MODS.
   Issues include:
          Resp failure
          Large lung mass (likely small cell), airway collapse, R
   effusion
          Svc syndrome
          R pnx (CT in palce with lung reinflated)
          VAP

   sedation
          Tachycardia
atrial fib

          Hypernatremia (resolved)
   Pt is in MODS with underlying aggressive lung malignancy  and shows
   continued clinical decline.  Her prognosis is extremely poor.  We
   continue to update family regarding worsening status and to address
   goals of care who fully understand her critical condition.
   Pt
s respiratory failure is multifactorial, [**2-10**]
   malpositioning/migration of ETT between stent and tracheal wall,
   extrinsic and intrinsic narrowing of distal trachea and bronchi [**2-10**]
   lung mass, probable underlying COPD, and RLL and LLL (retrocardiac)
   infiltrates concerning for pneumonia (VAP), plugging.  She remains
   tachy in afib and hypotensive.  At this time we are limited as to
   options to further temporize.  Giving additional fluids is contributing
   to volume overload with third spacing and tense abd distention in
   setting of progressive renal decline (progressively anuric), further
   impacting her resp status, now with increasing O2 needs and high airway
   presssures.  She remains unresponsive off sedation X days, likely toxic
   metabolic from uremia and infection.  Work up with eeg, LP, and head ct
   has been unrevealing.
   --We will stop fluids and compensate as able with vent.
   --We will check bladder pressures for compartment syndome
   --Dialysis would further prolong course in this patient and is unlikely
   to change to her overall prognosis.
   --Continue ACV support.  We will decrease her TV to lower pips/plts and
   accept ph > 7.2, Decrease fio2 and accept pao2 > 65.
    --We have discussed and evaluated for a broad ddx of her a-fib and
   hypotension (including infection, tension PTX, PE, rv compression from
   mass/decreasing CO and preload from mass, cardiac tamponade and cardiac
   ischemia).   This appears mutlifactorial and largely related to
   underlying infection and lung mass.
   -- We continue empiric antiibx (vanco,cipro,cef).
   Remainder as per resident note.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 58-year-old female with respiratory failure due to a newly diagnosed lung cancer (likely small cell) caused by superior vena cava (SVC) syndrome, airway compromise requiring Y-stent placement, and pneumonia. The patient has been admitted for radiation therapy and chemotherapy but has shown a progressive clinical decline and multi-organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS). 

The patient's respiratory failure is multifactorial, including malpositioning/migration of endotracheal tube (ETT), extrinsic and intrinsic narrowing of the distal trachea and bronchi, lung mass, underlying chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), right lower lobe (RLL) and left lower lobe (LLL) infiltrates concerning for pneumonia (ventilator-associated pneumonia or VAP), and plugging. The patient remains tachycardic in atrial fibrillation (AFib) and hypotensive. 

The patient is unresponsive off sedation and likely toxic from metabolic uremia and infection. Other issues include thrombocytopenia/pancytopenia, hypernatremia (resolved), acute renal failure (ARF), and decreased level of consciousness.

Assessment and Plan:

1. Continue aggressive care in the ICU.
2. Stop fluids and compensate as able with ventilation.
3. Check bladder pressures for compartment syndrome.
4. Dialysis would further prolong the patient's course and is unlikely to change

Summary:
Based on the information provided in the progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old female with respiratory failure due to a newly diagnosed lung cancer, likely small cell lung cancer, causing superior vena cava (SVC) syndrome and airway compromise requiring a Y-stent. The patient is admitted for radiation therapy and chemotherapy but has experienced a progressive clinical decline.

The patient's current condition includes respiratory failure, small cell lung cancer, airway collapse, right pleural effusion, SVC syndrome, right pneumonia, ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), altered mental status, tachycardia, hypotension, acute kidney injury (ARF), thrombocytopenia, hypernatremia, and pancytopenia.

The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation with an endotracheal tube in place. There are concerns about malpositioning/migration of the ETT, extrinsic and intrinsic narrowing of the distal trachea and bronchi, lung mass, underlying chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and right lower lobe (RLL) and left lower lobe (LLL) infiltrates concerning for pneumonia.

The patient's respiratory status is complicated by volume overload, higher FiO2 requirements, and higher pressures. The patient's abdomen is tense, and she is nearly anuric. The patient is also showing signs of multiorgan dysfunction, including renal failure and hepatic dysfunction.
